So I did not hear anything for a while, contacted the surgery and found out that some mistake had occured at the practice & the request had not been placed/ got lost in the system. Then I saw my regular GP who chased it up. The scan was done at a private clinic as part of NHS partnership. So I had Radiotherapy 2014: Jan 22nd- Feb 12 , began Anastrozole & Adcal Dec 2013, had Base Density Scan May 2014. I have placed a reminder for a follow up in my calendar for March 2015. The result I had in May, read by my regular GP ( a diamond) shows that I'm heading towards Osteoporosis. So my recommendation would be start tel/ texting/emailing Breast Care Nurse, Oncology Dept, GP and find out who's organising this scan? I think it could vary from place to place. Wish you well. Love Judith xxx

Posts.Content: Hi Susie, A big welcome to you! Are you getting support with the Lymphoedema, do you have MLD? I had a WLE Nov 2013, 4 clear Lymph Nodes removed and then Radiotherapy: which finished Feb 2014. Since then I've had 2-3 bouts of Cellulitis in the breast operated on. Then in October 2014, had an official diagnosis with Professor Mortimer ( Lymphoedema Consultant) one of 2 in England, saw Professor Mortimer at his clinic at  The Royal Marsden Hospital in Sutton for an initial consultation & diagnosis. Then I saw Mary Woods Senior Lymphoedema Nurse at The Royal Marsden Hospital in Chelsea. I requested a referral to Professor Mortimer via my GP who faxed the request to his secretary. Though depending on where you live,a  referral may need to come from the Oncologist. Professor Mortimer has an interest in secondary Lymphoedema as a result of breast cancer treatment. The details for Lymphoedema Consultants in the UK and elsewhere can be found at the Lymphoedema  Support Network: www.lymphoedema.org  I have paid my subscription and receive regular information. Also I have a medical alert card as part of my membership with the LSN. I am now taking Penicillin as a prophylactic ( low dose) for a year at least. So far the Cellulitis has kept away! It is a good idea too to wear a good support bra. I did not for a long time as this was not pointed out to me by the BC Nurse/ BC Team etc.Professor Mortimer recommended a sports bra & non wired. So I bought the Marks & Spencer 2 pack, one black, one white it comes in a wide range of sizes. I see a local Lymphoedema nurse who's paid by the local health trust to provide MLD to patients with Lymphoedema following treatment for breast cancer. I try to do regular exercise, but not wear myself out, I ache in the scar area and under arm pit area if I'm over tired. Keep the area clean & well moisturised with E45 cream regularly, don't use a disposable razor there and avoid carrying heavy loads on that side of your body. Also avoid extremes of temp eg too hot baths etc &  avoid midge bites,   cuts, scratches or grazes ( I carry Savlon with me everywhere). Apologies if you know most of this already! I feel it is better to have too much information & detail rather than too little. I wish you well. Hugs to you! Judith xx

Posts.Content: Hi Monika, There is a useful website for the Lymphoedema Support Network (LSN). It is www.lymphoedema.org. You could ask your GP if they ( or the Oncologist) would refer you for an appointment with a Lymphoedema Consultant eg Professor Peter Mortimer, who has Lymphoedema Clinics at various hospitals eg Royal Marsden in Sutton & TRM in Chelsea. He also can be located at St George's. If you contact his secretary, Google she will tell you which has the shortest waiting list. There are other consultants elsewhere in the UK, info at LSN. Posts.Title: question

Posts.Content: Hi Julia, I joined the LSN as was officially diagnosed by Professor Mortimer  with Lymphoedema ( with Cellulitis) in October 2014. Previous to that probably since the WLE, & 4 Lymph. Nodes removal on November 2013, I had bouts of Cellulitis which required courses of Antibiotics. Recommendations for Antibiotics are at www.lymphoedema.org. I was also advised by the Oncologist and Profesdor Mortimer to see the local ( NHS funded) Lymphoedema practitioner or nurse( details for registered ones on LSN). I received the care sheets free as I had taken out a membership of the LSN. The Radiated area, without complications  can take up to 18 months to settle down I was told. Cellulitis can develope into Lymphoedema which is why it's important to monitor any changes in the area. For Cellulitis that would be heat, pink or redness, pain and swelling. I have Lymphoedema in the breast area. Lymphoedema is a condition which can develop at any point, and affects approximately a quarter of people who have breast cancer surgery/treatment. It also affects people who undergo other types of surgery and treatment too.   Heat ( extremes of temperature are not helpful for Lymphoedema), it is advisable to drink lots of fluid and keep the affected area out of the sun. Also to avoid skin breakage or damage on the affected quadrant of the body ( where the Lymph channels try to flow). I believe that Tenerife does not have Mosquitos, trying to find a positive here;-)  As Helen says, if in doubt check it out!!  My GP was excellent and first diagnosed the Cellulitis in 2013. Judith xx

Posts.Content: Hi Amy 66, Regarding Radiotherapy have you been offered a DEXA Scan to measure your bone density ?  Will you be taking tablets ( AI's) to remove Oestrogen? I had  Rads Jan- Feb 2014.  Before they started I had 2 tattoos for the Radiologists to line up the beam. They are in blue ink and look like biro smudges, especially the one near my WLE breast. Not minute, suppose it depends on skill of tattooist.  The Rads do not hurt, it can take time to get the body lined up for the treatment. The Radiologists who treated me in Brighton Hospital were all  very kind and patient. I was advised to put E 45 cream on my treated area twice a day, which I did for 6 months. After treatment finished I felt   really tired for about 6 weeks. I think Rads : 1& 2 creams are available in some areas.  The after effects of WLE & Rads took about 18 months to settle down. I developed Cellulitis a bacterial infection  ( poss from surgery) and was  on antibiotics a number of months, then developed Lymphoedema in op breast which again settled down following Manual Lymphatic Drainage (MLD) with a Lymphoedema nurse,via NHS ( referred by the Oncologist ).    I do have some Radiotherapy damage to chest wall, inflammation called Tieze's syndrome which means that the breast feels like it has a deep bruise all the time. ( I also had 10 titanium markers left post op in the breast for the Radiologists,  I was told a year later  by a doctor examining an X-ray with me)  Remember to drink lots of fluid and take books or music to listen to while waiting for the Rads room. Judith xx

Posts.Content: Hi Arthen   Anastrozole is the generic make for the original brand:  Arimidex made by Astra Zeneca. I was on the generic and found different side effects with each brand. For me Accord  did not suit. Sandoz did. However the local Pharmacist ran out of the generic and gave me one month‘s Prescription for Arimidex and I noticed a definite decrease in SE’s and improvement. The main side effect on Arimidex was insomnia. If your symptoms are particularly bad you could make a case to your GP as I did. It took 3 months of reminders to GP and Oncologist ( due to significant price of Arimidex). After 3 months my GP relebted and prescribed Arimidex.   Judith xx

Posts.Content: Hello, Keep an eye on the area, if it gets worse e.g. Redness/ pinkness increases, gets warm/hot to touch  and more painful, and swollen, & temperature,    then there may be an infection called Cellulitis, which will require a course of antibiotics. Untreated Cellulitis can result in  A&E. Foliowing a Lumpectomy, 4 Lymph Nodes removed and Radiotherapy I developed Cellulitis ( spotted by my GP), followed by Lymphoedema.  It took a few months of antibiotics followed by massage with a Lymphoedeman Practitioner  ( NHS). Eventually the area settled down, it was in the operated breast only.  Get it checked if you are not sure. Judith xx

Posts.Content: Hi Cannon, I wonder about the exhaustion too. I had a WLE, Rads 2013-14, ( then Cellulitis & Lymphoedema in op breast luckily both gone now). I started Anastrozole in Dec 2013 then went onto Arimidex ( initially for 5 yrs, now 10 yrs). I am 60 yrs work full time, live alone ( well have a rescue house cat >^••^<. ),I cannot afford to retire. Following a week's commute to London all I want to do is rest.  Since 2012, I've had a relationship break up, both parents died, diagnosis of breast cancer,  plus an eye op!! The joys of old age eh?!?.  I also take 60 mg daily of Duloxetine ( Cymbaltum) anti -depressant for reasons, see above. I was reading about the side effects of this anti depressant yesterday and exhaustion can be one of them. I am going to reduce and gradually stop taking them. I don't like taking the Arimidex either,  but my Oncologist has persuaded me to keep taking it.  You seem to be doing all the right things. I saw a fitness trainer who works with older people, on Sat. I was unaware that the older you get there, is muscle loss. So I'm going to do some gentle ( esp on weak side) weight lifting. She also knows someone who has had bc who is now a nutritionist so that may help too. I would like to get advice about my requirements as probably lacking some Vit or minerals?   Sleep is very important too, I'm still working on that one and a social life :-) Judith xxx

Posts.Content: Hi Lucy, Agreed with all you wrote. I don't want to have to think of cancer returning at some point in the future. I am currently taking the prescribed medication post treatment with reluctance. Some days I can feel rage returning at the seeming randomness of it all. But would I have felt better if a test had told me with some accuracy that I was likely to develop cancer in a given time span? No. It is random, so being afraid constantly will not make any difference, just result in further stress and lack of sleep. In my case anyway. I worry about Lymphoedema spreading all down my arm and hand, which could happen, so every scar ache, or change in sensation I picture it happening... Really,  what my rational self says is we must try to look after ourselves,  but not obsess as it won't help with recovery. But in the early hours easier said than done. I wonder if this shock could be a likened to PTSD or is this too dramatic to say? I find that music and stupid comedy helps as laughing can counteract gloomy thoughts. Wish you well. Love Judith xx

Posts.Content: Hi Chloe Cat 45, Thank you for this list which is very comprehensive and interesting! Thank you for listing all the different items! I was going to ask which brand of Anastrozole you are taking, then read back through some of the older  posts and saw TEVA.  I wondered if you had ever taken Arimidex ( Astra Zeneca) & if so how you found Anastrozole & Arimidex compare? I was taking Anastrozole Sandoz and have recently taken a month's emergency supply of Arimidex as the local Pharmacy had run out of Anastrozole. When I contacted the consultant via email for a prescription for Arimidex he left a voicemail to say that I should approach my GP for a prescription. This was a week ago. She had referred me to him for a prescription 2 weeks ago. I realise that Arimidex is far more costly and this is the reason why the consultant will not fax across a script to my GP. This is the second occasion that my GP referred me to the consultant as the expert in the field. I am now taking Accord as the choice at the Pharmacy was TEVA or Accord and I did not know which to take. In view of your previous comments re Accord it will be interesting to see how it affects me.  I do not take any extra multi Vits/ mins at present. I am putting Turmeric powder and black pepper over evening meal as a nutritionist recommended this at a Say Yes to Life talk I attended a year ago. I wish all the supplements you are taking came in one massive pill :-)  I'm considering drinking green tea again, but don't like it. I drink  1-2 cups of  flat white :coffee per day.  Rest : Celestial Seasonings Bengal Spice Herbal Tea.  Do you have any views please  on "Bio-Kult "which contains 14 live bacterial cultures? Also "Beta Glucan " by Viridian? I'm taking penicillin each day as a Prophalatic ( avoid reoccurrence of cellulitis),  and feel nauseous each morning as a result. Also gives me diarrhoea sometimes. I realise that taking food supplements/ Vits/ mins/ is a very individual thing. I want to try to assist my health as much as possible.( Though I don't drink enough water :-/.) Might add I don't eat meat at all, avoid bread ( don't like it), drink little alcohol: now not with ex. Try to eat more eggs than in past. I love broccoli, carrots (cooked), fennel (raw), chicory/ endive (raw) rocket, avocados, nuts/ nut spreads, apples, blueberries poached salmon( M&S), tomatoes, lemons, oat cakes, cheese,  Tahini, olive oil. Weakness for chocolate :-/  ? Tell myself it's giving me iron :-[] Must admit  as I live on own, not keen on cooking at all, so vegs in the microwave with some fish/ cheese or nut spread does me fine. After work all I want to do is rest. ! Thank you for reading this far .... Judith xxx

Posts.Title: Chemo and deodorant

Posts.Content: Hi Ally70, Welcome to the forum, good to have you on board! I agree it is important not to risk any cuts or scratches which may happen with disposable razors. My Breast Care Nurse  also advised using an electric or battery shaver. However, I would be wary however of using Veet as it may contain chemicals which could cause reactions in sensitive skin that is undergoing Chemo or Rads. I had a WLE 4 LNs removed followed by Radiography. I washed the pits using mild soap. Did not start with a deodorant until completed Rads, then used a Green People Roll on deodorant : Aloe Vera ( which has no harsh chemicals eg Aluminium and Parabens). Some believe that an accumulation of such chemicals in the Lymph glands is very unhealthy, and possibly tumour forming; though others dispute these findings.  After Radiotherapy I prefer to be a bit cautious with what I stick under my arm pits now. :-)  Love Judithxx

Posts.Content: Hello Everyone, This is a general query. I had a WLE & 4 LNs removed Nov 2013. Rads Jan-Feb 2014.  Currently taking: Anastrozole 1mg: daily,  Adcal D3: 1,500mg x2 daily, Penicillin Phenoxymethylpenicillin 250mg x 2 twice daily, ( to keep Cellulitis at bay), Citalopram 20mg x 1 daily. I'm estrogen positive so avoiding foods etc with that. I had a flu jab in early November 2014. Recently I have had 3 heavy colds in 2 months. I don't know what to do to improve my immune system? Any suggestions please ? I would really appreciate it, sitting here with streaming nose. I have problems sleeping too. I eat broccoli practically every day! Think that the daily penicillin could be a factor, but I've been advised to take it as a Prophalatic for a year.   Thank you. Judithx

Posts.Content: Hi Maggie, I have been on Citalopram 20mg daily since being diagnosed Nov 2013. The irony is that I had come off them completely at stage of diagnosis, but I was so shocked & angry that I asked to go back on them. My dad (90yrs) died 3 years ago and my ex split up with me, then I was diagnosed with BC. I have a 90yr old mum who lives in the country and does not know I've had breast cancer, as she deals with shock badly: emotionally collapses. I work full time and that keeps me going, and my mind occupied . Due to life events I don't have a family or relatives ( my parents both had difficult upbringings).  I live alone and find it hard. I am socialising, but it's a fine line between that and seeming "desperate "for company! Which let's face it is not attractive generally.  I think that if Anti depressants will support you relax, and get more sleep (do not work for me there :-( ) it's something to look into definitely.  Wish you well. e hug Judith xxx

Posts.Content: Hi Ali, I will be thinking of you tomorrow:-) I had the titanuim (for the tit), marker inserted previously to the date of my Op November 22nd 2013. On the morning,  they inserted a wire, then I traveled to the hospital by hospital transport with my ex, for the op.  I was very nervous! First op in hospital at 56 yrs. everyone: all the nurses, the admin staff the anaesthetist ( really kind) and the surgeon were totally lovely. Princess Royal Alexandra  Hospital Hayward's Heath.  I had the anaesthetic, WLE  4 LNs removed  and woke up in the recovery area, then went home same afternoon with taxi. I had no sickness/ nausea. Was very tired next couple of days and rested. I actually started the breast exercises as soon as I had recovered from op. Did exercises twice a day, for months and got good use of arm and no cording.  Lots of love to you for tomorrow Ali :-) Best wishes to Pepper Noir too  xxxxx Judith.

Posts.Content: Hi Kate,  I had a WLE & 4 LNs removed in Nov 2013, followed by Rads Jan-Feb 2014. Since then I have had cellulitis, lots of anti biotics,  4-5 UTIs and mild Lymphoedema in the WLE operated breast!  I am 58yrs on Arimidex Astra Zeneca, Adcal VitD3, Citalopram 20 mg daily, Penicillin VK 500 mg daily ( to prevent reoccurrence of cellulitis,). I feel tired 70% of the time now. I commute daily from Brighton to London 4 days per week, & work from home on Fridays. I live alone, only 90yrs mum who lives in Wales. So every break visit her as no siblings.  I worry that the Lymphoedema will spread down my arm, but this is not an emotionally healthy way to live; so apart from sensible precautions to the op side quadrant of the body eg kitchen gloves for peeling vegetables and cleaning out the bath/ washing up- Also try to avoid cuts/ sunburn/scratches/ hot water/ harsh chemicals/bumps/burns/bites etc that is all I can do to prevent further infection.  Each day,  I have aching joints especially my back, and arm/ wrist on right side( right handed). I take Bio-Kult Pro-Cyan Pro Biotic from  Boots to help my gut ( penicillin each day). Also take Floradix Tablets to provide iron & Vits B& C. I am thinking about Glucosamine & Chondroitin and Magnesium.I try to eat healthily ( but too much chocolate if I'm honest .)  I find it difficult to relax and sleep well at night, though I think a pair of rescue Siamese cats would probably help !☺️ I saw a  Lymphoedema consultant last October who recommended wearing a sports bra, and not underwired ever again. My skin is sensitive following radiation, so even a soft bra feels rough.   Why should you have to " grin & bear it" feeling rough? Do you see a counsellor at all? I am seeing one at present for CBT, and find it useful. You are not alone Kate!! Keeping active is a good strategy. I did the recommended exrecises 2x daily for months- and did not get cording. I do them still but not so often.  Also walking helps when I feel irritable too. Look after yourself. Love from Judith xxx
Posts.Title: Breast pain and low energy 8 months on.

Posts.Content: Hi Monika, It is hard isn't it ! I had a WLE 4 LNs removed at same time ( Nov 2013), then Rads Jan-Feb 2014. I feel tired 70% of time now. I wear an M&S  sports bra as have mild Lymphoedema. I went without a bra initially & then had Cellulitus : an infection following the Lumpectomy & this resulted in Lymphoedema. Luckily, I have not had cording & try to keep my arms flexible to avoid this. I find it really hard to relax & often have insomnia and consider the Arimidex medication a factor in this.My thoughts sometimes go round in circles from redundancy to secondaries!  More so when I'm exhausted.  Sending you a virtual hug. Judith xxx

Posts.Content: Hi again , Good morning, yes I was told by my BC Nurse that the physical side effects can last up to a year. I still have side effects if you see on my profile. I agree with JMWatson it is important to speak to someone. I am waiting for further counselling: CBT, NHS funded so there is a waiting list. Maybe if you ring the Macmillan Helpline and see what's in your local area. Also do insist that you get a BC Nurse via the hospital or clinic you visited, if that's local to you.I saw two before found present BC Nurse who is kind and listens, also reads & answers emails. I live alone so this makes a great difference to me. I hope that you get some support very soon. Love Judith xxx
Posts.Title: nearly 10 months out if chemo and still feeling poo :(

Posts.Content: Hi, I'm sorry that you are feeling so low. You have been through such a lot and at a young age too. When I was diagnosed with BC last November 6th, I was so angry I wanted to murder people. Then I was in shock for a long while. I feel down a lot on Anastrozole, tired, have joint pain & I think it's affected my eyesight too. In that it's more blurry, I had a cataract operated on and an implant about 7 yrs ago. The other eye seems to have got worse ( have a cataract in left eye too) & needs an implant in the new year according to Optometrist. I make myself go for walks and exercise. Most of time I have no energy. I also have insomnia which is difficult as my mind will not shut off. I would suggest that you contact the hospital or clinic where you had treatment and request a Breast Care Nurse. Let the BC Team there know that you need some emotional support at this point. Also you could see if there's a Macmillan Counsellor in the clinic/ hospital. I saw a counsellor for three months. I attend a Breast Cancer Support group held once a month at local Breast Care Centre. Maybe ring Macmillan and see what services / provision is available where you live. Is there more than one GP at your practice? Could you see another one? You also don't need to pay for prescriptions any more if you've had cancer. Get the form from your Drs surgery. I hope that some of this helps. It is always hard with not enough sleep! I know this. Look after yourself. Love Judith xx

Posts.Title: Feeling down today ....

Posts.Content: Hi Andreecorky and all,  Since 2012, life has been "difficult".  So I tend to think "Why" too! My dad (90) died in Jan 2012, my ex decided that same year after losing a lot of weight  that he wanted to relive his youth, at the age of 52. I moved from London to Brighton in 2013. I was diagnosed with BC in November 2013, had a WLE, followed by complications. Now better.  May 2016, my mum (92) died suddenly ( DVT), which has completely floored me! I have no family at all now, (  no brothers, sisters nor children ), except a cousin ( my mum & her brother were both adopted ). My dad had a difficult upbringing and as a consequence, so did I.  I live alone,  though with a strong willed cat! I try to get out there and socialise but  it is bloody hard! Believe it or not a very good sense of humour is buried beneath all this current gloom.  The Arimidex ( 10yrs ), makes me feel tired and years older than 59.  I'm off work through depression ( pretty obvious) have  just started counselling with CRUSE. I contacted the new Macmillan Horizon Cancer Centre in Brighton to see if they offer a " Moving on " course, they don't ! .So I am going to suggest that it might be an idea to do so. I did not let my mum know I had cancer as I did not want to burden her and now she has died I keep thinking that cancer will return, which is not a way to live.  Judith x

Posts.Title: Feeling down today ....

Posts.Content: Hi Denise,  Read your post & agree with all you say. The News presents us with generally negative " news". ( apart from the occasional Royal Baby / politician photo op) !  When you have stress & insomnia ( snap !!!), it makes everything much more difficult to cope with. I finished treatment Feb 2014. I too worry that it will return : unannounced!  I had no noticeable symptoms in Nov 2013. Worry is hard to damp down:-/ I take 20mg of Citalopram daily, work full time & try to eat properly ( mostly) & get regular exercise ( usually)! I will not watch "The c word" as I know that I would find it depressing. I get enough of that already ;-) with work,  & politicians rambling on about their promises (!) to create a better,more just society..!!! Haah! I hope that I can do some good in my work with unemployed young people instead.   In terms of lack of sleep, I refuse to take sleeping tablets as on Arimidex, AdCal VitD, Citalopram, plus Magnesium,  Vit B, & Pro Biotics!! Enough. Stopped taking daily Penicillin VK to prevent recurrence of Cellulitis as had daily Diarrorhea also:-/  Saw Onc in April 2015, & he said recovery from WLE, 4 LNs  removal & Rads was still ongoing! ( did not know that it takes this long).  I'm going to start CBT ( via GP referral) later this month and hypnotherapy via Macmillan Pychological Therapies Counsellor referral as have average 4 hrs sleep. Not really slept well since diagnosis Nov 2013. Always poor sleeper, even worse now! I live alone since ex split up with me 2yrs ago. That's certainly hard to deal with! I miss his company not his moods. Hopefully getting a cat May 17th :-) ( also sponsoring a Staffie Cross via The Dogs' Trust too). I don't have family close by, only have mum 91y in Wales. I have joined 14 Meet Up Groups so there should be some upbeat people there ! Enjoy your family and friends & try not to dwell on what ifs .. Big hug Judith xxx

Posts.Content: Hi Lilianc, This is an interesting Post! I had a WLE in Nov 2013, & 4 clear Lymph Nodes removed. In Jan- Feb 2014 I had Radiotherapy.  Soon after I developed Cellulitis in the op breast & then Lymphoedema. I had a GP Referral to Prof Peter Mortimer at The Royal Marsden in Sutton and he prescribed VK Penicillin for a year initially ( Cellulitis got better before then). Lymphoedema in op  breast is under control.  Towards the end 2014, I developed a riash  of itchy red marks under my bra line around the area where I had Rads. I saw my GP & asked for a referral to a Dermatologist.  I saw a Dermatologist in Brighton County Hospiral she examined them & said they were age related !! I find this hard to believe as I don't have them anywhere else and I'm 59 not 89! Yesterday I noticed another spot which is red, itchy & sore on the bra line. What I would like to know is, what are these? Are they an after effect of Radiation Treatment? Or are they in the wart / verruca family?   I also have a deep pain in the WLE breast and saw the Breast  Care Team Head Consultant at Royal Sussex Hospital who said the pain was caused by Radiation damage to the chest wall which could be temp or permanent and is known as Tieze's syndrome.   The pain is there with any pressure eg my cat placing one paw on my breast!  I'm going to follow up the red spots with another GP. Judith xx

Posts.Title: feeling so sad and angry after having had breast cancer

Posts.Content: Hello, This is an interesting topic of conversation. My mother died In May this year  and dad in 2012. I am also an only child and would have prefered to have had siblings. When I was diagnosed with breast  cancer in 2013 my ex  came with me to my early treatment sessions ( I think out of guilt). He is currently dating a girlfriend 24 yrs younger than himself.  He is reliving his youth.  I don't have children, I read a term recently for this growing trend :  " social infertility". I spent years going on blind dates:  The Guardian, Time Out, Classic FM,  started when I was 22yrs , , travel : I visited countries on my own hoping to meet " the one"en route. I spent a number of years also not actively looking and still nothing happened.   I taught English in Italy  for one year and guess what ...nothing.  My last holiday, before I got together with my ex ( I met on a speed date) & who didn't  want children,  was a week in Sweden and Gotland  on my own, no I did not meet anyone.. Through the years, I have tried indoor rock climbing, joined various evening classes, went to parties, BTCV project in Norway etc etc  all to no avail !  I went out briefly with a Norwegian, but he did not want commitment ( had a 15yr son lived with his ex ),  just talked about food all the time ( his ex was a chef, hell I even queued up for James Martin's autograph for him).  When he described my interest in vintage and antiques as " old crap" then I thought thats it, enough.  My mother who had been adopted, was shy, generally pessimistic,  and had no friends,  This had an impact on me, I also had an unsettled childhood as they moved a lot. Different schools etc.  However I consider myself a sociable person in essence.   I have joined Meet Up and hope to get a social circle through that. My close school friend lives 7 hrs & 30 mins away in Wales.  Other friends, people from the past now live in Canada and New Zealand. I visited New Zealand in the 1990s. People change, a few years back a " friend" I met  at college who eventually got the lifestyle she desired in Chiswick, spent a lot of  time telling me how unhappy her marriage was, but how she could not afford to divorce.  When I subsequently contacted her regarding my own break up she was too busy studying a Prue Leith Diploma course  to see me.  I agree, it is not easy when you are alone and older.  I've contacted someone on Street Life App who's organising a get together for people on their own at Christmas in my local area.  This will be my first Christmas with no family.  Judith xx.

Posts.Content: Hi ash7 My cholesterol is higher than yours. This was indicated to me yesterday by the nurse who took my bloods at the GP surgery. I had asked for a blood test to find out the following areas:  cholesterol calcium thyroid magnesium potassium and vits in addition to usual areas.  A practice nurse at the surgery about 2 yrs ago suggested that I go on statins. Her precise words were:” I recommend everyone over 50 takes them”. This immediately put me off High blood cholesterol could be a genetic factor, my mum had raised blood cholesterol and she was skinny and lived to 92yrs. Diet and stress could be contributing factors too.  Many medical companies” probably”  encourage GPs and aligned staff to promote statins for profit ? Or am I being cynical There are side effects with statins as with most drugs.  I think you have to weigh up the pros and cons. I am on enough drugs as it is  already,  so unless I can see the benefits, I prefer to pass on them.  Judith xx

Posts.Content: Hi AliG58, I'm a 36G following the op ( Lymphoedema swelling on op side), so wear as recommended by the Lymp consultant a soft sports bra. I get them 2 in a pack one white/one black from M&S. I was advised not to wear under wired ever again. Please remember to do the arm exercises daily and don't take too much on, until you feel stronger. Sleep helps too :-) Judith xx
Posts.Title: TM

Posts.Content: Hi Denise, I have been taking Anastrozole since Dec. 6th 2013.  Since that time I've developed aching joints and have bad insomnia. I requested Arimidex from my Oncologist at a check up in October 2014. He informed me that I would be taking the medication for 10yrs instead of 5 yrs & stated  that I need to speak to my GP about a prescription for Arimidex. When I let her know this , she said that it was not her area of professional expertise and that it was up to the Oncologist to decide. My local Pharmacist ran out of Anastrozole just before Christmas and had one month's emergency supply of Arimidex ( Registered maker Astra Zeneca).  I took Arimidex over Christmas and noticed an improvement & less joint pain. So I sent an email to the Oncologist's secretary requesting a script for Arimidex and I stated that the GP had referred me back to him. The Oncogist left me a voicemail message saying that he did  not have an issue with me taking Arimidex rather than Anastrozole, and said that it was the GP who would make that decision.  I am currently taking Anastrozole Accord brand and the aching is spreading to my shoulders and back. I had a basic bone density scan last May ( as no one told me I had to organise it via my GP). The results showed that I am moving towards Osteo porosis.  I feel tired and fed up, very hard  to work full time on an average of 4.5 hours sleep per night.  I believe it is the inactive cheap fillers which cause the side effects, in. Anastrozole but I could be wrong here.  Judith xx

Posts.Content: Hi Eric, Sleeping pills are useful I feel as a short term measure. My first occasion in hospital was in 1987 ( prolapsed disc) which necessitated two weeks traction & one week bed rest. I was initially in a corridor in a busy North London Hospital, & by day three ( had made it into a ward) was so tired and emotional that I readily took the sleeping tablets offered by the nurses. I am currently taking Anastrozole, Ad Cal, Citalopram & Co-Amoxiclav. I don't wish to become reliant or addicted to sleeping tablets. In fact I don't like taking Citalopram either, I took it when diagnosed with Breast Cancer last November as could not contend with my feelings of rage & aggression. Since my diagnosis I have tried to ease my over active mind by meditation & to an extent this has helped. I note that you are a Buddhist. The internet is a truly marvellous invention! :-) I have looked at your blog and am very impressed by your determination and positive outlook in life in general and your achievements. You have used your influence for good and to aid humanity. We need politicians with your standards today. You are an inspiring individual. I hope that your health remains stable & if I reach an advanced age ( my mother is 90y) & my father was 90y, so there is a fair possibility, then I may well take a sleeping pill if I still have insomnia! I wish you well, Regards Judith xx
Posts.Title: Can't sleep

Posts.Content: Hi Madhatter 1, When I saw the Oncologist in Oct 2014, he wished to change me from Anastrozole to Tamoxifen. However, I had read some where that there may be an increased risk of endometrial cancer with Tamoxifen and stated this to the Oncogist as a reason for my reluctance to change. I had also been informed by a nurse at The Royal Marsden Hospital ( Fulham), that a study was being undertaken by the hospital as to why so many women were stopping taking Tamoxifen. I saw Professor Mortimer at the RMH who diagnosed Lymphoedema & Cellulitis in the breast I'd had the WLE . So I'm taking penicillin for a year to stop the Cellulitis from reoccuring in addition to Anastrozole and Adcal VitD3.  I feel worried about the side effects associated with Tamoxifen, as it is an older drug and I can't face anything worse than I'm taking already.  I really don't know what to do apart from hassle my GP and see if she will write a script for Arimidex. ( Astra Zeneca).  The Oncologist said that if I took Tamoxifen then I could also take a topical oestrogen cream as the risk with this is very low. But I just feel worried and stressed as these AIs are supposed to be stripping the body of oestrogen so this  seems counter productive? Judithxx

Posts.Content: Hi Lynne, I am sorry that the TV advert reminded you of a very difficult period which you had to face, some of the treatment on your own. I was diagnosed November 6 2013. So getting nearer to an anniversary I 'd rather not remember too. My ex was there for me whilst I had my operation in hospital ( although he was texting his girlfriend just as I was due in theatre). I had been supporting him financially so his obvious reason for being there was not entirely altruistic. He came to my initial Radiotherapy treatment session because I was scared, I attended all the subsequent ones on my own. The TV advert is probably hard for many people to see, because it means different responses for individuals. The popular image is of a loving family and support group of friends flocking around, that is not the case for a great number of people unfortunately! Also many people with a support network can still feel very isolated as you pointed out in your email. The knowledge that you had that inner strength to go through that treatment will never leave you. It is brilliant to know that Macmillan is here for everyone and a rock to all. !!! Love Judith xxx :-D

Posts.Content: Hi Genorm, I got to Yr4 on Arimidex and was diagnosed with secondary breast cancer 04/01/18. My sbc was picked up on a CT Scan arranged by my GP who is married to an Oncologist. I had symptoms of back pain and diarrhoea : these are SE of Arimidex.  If the GP had not arranged this my sbc near Aorta would not have been picked up.  Why should you not receive a bone scan? I would ask for Scans etc, speak to your breast care nurse/ team GP/ Oncologist/ Oncologist Secretary etc email people and copy others into emails it usually gets more of a response I find.  Wish you well with appointments. Judith xxxx

Posts.Content: Hi Suzyjane, Please get support from Macmillan, there's a helpline , you could ask them to let you know what's in your local area eg Macmillan in the community. Is there a Macmillan Buddies or Volunteer scheme for example?  My ex broke up with me about the same time as I was diagnosed in November 2013 at the age of 56yrs. I went through the majority of treatment on my own as have no family apart from my mum who's 91 yrs and can't deal with any kind of shock ( she does not know I've had breast cancer). So I know what it's like to feel very alone.  You could contact Macmillan and ask them to intervene on your behalf with work? You are covered by the disability act. Technically work should not discriminate against you.  I saw a Macmillan Psychological Therapies Counsellor for three months at the hospital where I received treatment on a weekly basis and it helped a great deal. I was in shock at the time of diagnosis, my initial response was that I wanted to die too, as felt there was not much to live for, that I had a life in which I had achieved a lot of what is wished to achieve;  albeit no family or kids ( but I spent years trying to put that one in place), so give myself 10 out of 10 for effort :-) The Macmillan Psychological Therapies Counsellor also referred me to a charity called Odyssey who organise and pay for holidays for people recovering from cancer.  So in September 2014 I had a lovely week's holiday in the countryside in Kent. I think GPs or other Health Care Processionals can refer you also to Odyssey. I also went back onto Citalopram 20 mg anti depressant which I had come off, at point of diagnosis. This was because I knew that I didn't want to experience the total rage I felt, which probably shot my cortisol levels sky high! As the other ladies ( & G'nJ ) point out there are also local support groups for people too. Love Judith xxxx

Posts.Content: Hi Heather, Good to hear from you :-) Please don't apologise for the length of post. This is our forum and we can write as little or as much as we wish!!  I don't feel inclined to take Tamoxifen at all, if given a choice. I had very bad PMS every single month from when I started my periods until they ceased at the age of 52 yrs. It could be I was deficient in Magnesium all those years? I had seven days of the month, when I felt well, then the symptoms of PMS would build up so by day 27/28 I felt about to explode: fluid re tension, tender gums, sore eyes, back pain, feeling of pressure on my head, tender breasts. I had this every single month.  I tried: changing diet, taking evening primrose oil ( helped), homeopathy, Bach Flower remedies, herbal remedies, acupuncture ( helped), exercise( maybe I was magnesium lacking?). The GP recommended that I go on the pill for PMS, I refused as did not want another set of issues. I was dreading the Menopause as a result of my experience. However, my periods tailed off & it was such a relief!! The menopause was not an issue, never had a hot flush in my life or night sweats. This I see as a blessing after awful PMS thorough out my reproductive life. My mum had no problems with PMS at all, so I don't know why I did? She did however have fibroids and a total hysterectomy in her 40a, they took it out whilst she was under the anaesthetic.  I do believe that the inactive fillers are the cause of the side effects, otherwise why are some AIs more tolerable than others? I have not tried Cipla. Accord brand for me is dreadful the worst medication I've been on so far.!! I wonder if Femara would help me? I don't feel inclined to take Letrozole cheaper version, based on my experience of Anstrozole. Best wishes Judith xxx

Posts.Content: Hi everyone, Small note of caution, I had a WLE & 4 LNs removed in Nov 2013. This was followed by Rads Jan- Feb 2014. Due to the type/stage of cancer found I did not have Chemo. Following the surgery and Rads treatment, I developed Cellulitis 3-4 times & took  antibiotics as recommended by the Lymphoedema Support Network www.lymphoedema.org . Cellulitis is a bacterial infection which untreated can become accute and require an emergency hospital stay. Fortunately I took anti biotics  which dealt with it; however the result is, I have Lymphoedema in the operated breast. It is mild but there permanently. I take daily penicillin VK to avoid a recurrence of Cellulitis as recommended by Professor Mortimer. ( Lymphoedema consultant).   I would suggest, watch the op side( or sides) monitor any redness, heat, swelling or pain, in case it's Cellulitis. Don't carry heavy loads so as not to put a strain on Lymph nodes area, which have been operated on or removed. Avoid extremes of heat/cold, bites, scratches, bruises, cuts , skin breakages to affected side/ sides.  Not everyone who has had Breast Cancer & the surgery/ treatment goes on to develop Lymphoedema, it is approximately 25%. I would suggest wearing a supportive, unwired, sports type bra. I went without a bra following surgery As no one advised me to the contrary. Please do the arm exercises twice a day , this helps prevent cording which I did not get. I now wear a non wired M&S sports  bra which comes in a pack of two, one black, one white.  Do have daily exercise, this will help with your recovery and emotionally helps too. I found reflexology at the hospital where I was treated really helpful and relaxing. Exercise also helps with the side effects of hormone inhibitors,  if you have to take these little " treasures" too!! I'm on Arimidex Astra Zeneca for 10yrs, unless Onc decides to put the  number up again ... Sincerely hope not ;-)  Acupuncture is brilliant, I had it for really Bad PMS every month in the past,: 58 now:-) . I tried lots: Homeopathy, Bach Flower, Herbal Med, changing Diet, lots of long walks. Only Acupuncture helped a lot.  However, as I now have Lymphoedema ( which can develop at any stage in the future), I would suggest a conversation about inserting needles in the quadrant of the body that has been operated on? I will email my Lymphoedema practitioner about Acupuncture, as I found it very beneficial too! So I do agree with Julie's view but, with a caution as to possible consequences. It may be that if the area of Lymph Nodes is avoided then it is safe?  I would be interested to know the view/s of Acupunture practitioners regarding the possibility of developing Cellulitis/ Lymphoedema in affected body area via needle insertion, as the key phrase is " skin breakages." I will contact the secretary of Professor Mortimer Lymphoedema  Consultant too, for his views. If it is acceptable,  with the proviso of avoiding the quadrant, then I'm interested in Acupuncture as it can make a big difference I've found. Judith xx

Posts.Content: Hello everyone, I am 58 yrs on Feb 16th, and trying to sort out the Aromatase Inhibitors (AI) I am taking for the next 9 yrs as started Dec 2013. Diagnosis: 41mm, Grade 2 invasive lobular carcinoma of right breast associated with lobular neoplasia in situ. Lymphovasular invasion present. ER positive, PR negative, HER2 negative. 0/4 lymph nodes involved. WLE & sentinel node biopsy 25/11/13. I have been taking Anastrozole various makes the latest being Accord ( awful). Over Christmas my local Pharmacist ran out of the generics & gave me a month's emergency pack of Astra Zeneca Arimidex ( which I felt had less side effects). I contacted my GP for a prescription for Astra Zeneca Arimidex she referred me to the Oncoligist. I received a letter from his secretary yesterday. To summarise: he does not feel that inactive fillers are a factor in the side effects I experience from certain makes. He took part in a research team, which compared Anastrozle with Letrozole. " A good proportion of women preferred Letrozole over Anastrozole" ( why I ask?). His recommendation: I switch to Letrozole 2.5 mg daily ( note no mention of Femara in the letter). Then: " If you do not get on with Letrozole then I would suggest switching to Tamoxifen 20mg daily which is a selective oestrogen receptor modulator and often causes less arthralgia than the Aromatase Inhibitors". ( Tamoxifen may cause an increased risk of endometrial cancer). A nurse at The Royal Marsden Hospital in Sutton ( Lymphoedema clinic: told me that research was being undertaken by them as to why so many women stopped taking Tamoxifen). I would be very interested to hear peoples' views as feeling very fed up at this stage. I currently have insomnia, fatigue, no energy, back pain, joint pain down right hand side, searching for words, eyes hurt. Feel 90y , same age as my mum :-( I saw my Breast Care Nurse at the clinic yesterday she listened and commented that I should see a GP and let them know how bad I feel. Also that I should request Arimidex Astra Zeneca or Femara. I have my next appointment with the Oncologist 21/4/15. I take Adcal Vit D3 daily and penicillin V ( to stop Cellulitis ) 250mg daily. Please could other people let me know their experience and any advice please? !!! Thank you. Judith x

Posts.Content: Hi George, Thank you for your reply:-). I saw my BC Nurse last Friday and see encouraged me to let my GP know how bad I felt on Anastrozole ( Accord).  So I took along the empty Arimidex Astra Zeneca packet & the Accord Anasrozole pkt & she finally write me a script for Arimidex : taken 4 months to get it. I have not taken an AI since last Wed and notice a difference! My aching joints are much better . I should pick up prescription at Boots for Arimidex today after work. I also am on Trimethoprim currently as have another UTI so 2 lots of Anti Biotic at once! Maybe they will have a party & invite Citalopram & Ad Cal along :-D  Love Judith xx

Posts.Content: Hi I will beat this, I am sorry to hear about your diagnosis of Lymphoedema. The contact website is www.lymphoedema.org where lots of useful information can be found, on the treatment & management of this condition. I had a Lumpectomy, & 4 Lymph Nodes removed in Nov 2013, followed by Radiography Jan- Feb 2014. I subsequently developed Cellulitis ( bacterial infection) in either the Lumpectomy and/ or LN removal site OR where the titanium marker/s were left in the operated  breast.  I have taken courses of antibiotics over the last couple of years & have Lymphoedema in the operated breast. I stopped wearing regular bras after the operation in 2013 and now wear non wired, sports bras for support, 2 in a pack from Marks & Spencer. I still have deep pain in the breast, not at the operation site, but possibly where the marker/s are? I am looking into this currently.  I hope that you get the right course of treatment as this will make a difference. Judith xx

Posts.Content: Hi Tamsy, I had a WLE and 4 Lymph Nodes removed in Nov 2013, followed by Radiotherapy Jan- Feb 2014. The Oncologist wrote a recommendation for Anastrozole started it in Dec 2013. I have insomnia, fatigue, joint pain in hand shoulder ( right handed) back pain and general lack of energy. The generic form ( cheaper) of Anastrozole is mixed with inactive fillers. It is the inactive ingredients which are thought to cause the side effects in some people. I'm on the make Accord at present which is awful. I tried Arimidex Astra Zeneca the original registered drug, over Christmas for one month as the local Pharmacist ran out of Anastrozole : generic/ cheaper. I noticed an improvement in my side effects. My GP has not prescribed Arimidex Astra Zeneca ( due to cost) . The Oncologist wants me to try Letrozole. ( Registered expensive original is  Femara). I am reluctant to try Letrozole for the same reasons I don't like taking Anastrozole. The Oncologist last October suggested Tamoxifen, I said worried about the increased risk of endometrial cancer on Tamoxifen. He did not answer that question . The Royal Marsden Hospital in Sutton is currently under taking a survey into why some many women stop taking Tamoxifen. A nurse told me there while I was attending the Lymphoedema clinic for a diagnosis last October.  I was initially told would be on Hormone inhibitors for 5 years, then 10yrs last October 2014.  What do others think please? I know that some people have been successful in having prescriptions for Arimidex Astra Zeneca & Femara, but it seems to be an uphill struggle to be prescribed them. Love Judith xx.

Posts.Content: Hi Helen, I feel for you! Anastrozole causes me insomnia, depression back pain, vision deterioration and all round lack of energy. I was diagnosed with BC Nov6 13, had WLE, 4 clear Lymph Nodes removed. This was followed by Rads 22/1 - 12/2 2014. In June-July I developed Lymphoedema in breast operated on. Currently have Cellulitis, ( painful) and on Penicillin V Potassium for 3 months initially with a view to Prophalatic dose long term depending on results. I had the condition Lymphoedema & an infection confirmed this week at The Royal Marsden Hospital by a Lymphoedema Consultant. I commute an hour and half to London from Brighton. I live alone ( my ex and I split up last November after 10yrs ). I feel very alone at times, as have no family except my 90yr mum who was admitted to hospital last week. It's at times like these that I imagine that it would be good to have had children as I would not feel so lonely. Though my school friend in Wales divorced 10yrs ago and has had no contact with either of her two sons since then, even though she's a grandmother now. The Consultant ( and the nurse who spoke to me following the consultation) said that it would be useful to look at changing from Anastrozole. I am going to see if my Oncologist would prescribe Arimidex the original Registered drug to see if I can tolerate the inactive fillers better. I have joined social groups locally and try to get regular exercise as it helps. But it is hard when there is a lack of sleep to be positive. I have an Oncologist appointment on October 24th so will request a change of medication then. My BC Nurse is kind, but very busy. I shall see if she can attend or see me on the 24th October. I have made an appointment for CBT counselling, and on waiting list. I saw a counsellor for 3 months which helped at the hospital where I had Radiotherapy. I was also buddied up with a volunteer from Macmillan Community Buddies which also helped & was for 3 months too. I am going to look into the local Meet Up Groups. I attend a BC Support Group which meets the third Monday of each month for an hour & a half. I am going to look at getting work in Brighton, but as I'm employed by a Local Authority, this is probably going to be difficult. Truth is it is HARD to feel motivated when you don't feel well. The positive points of my day yesterday were finding £220 that someone dropped at Victoria Station, (the last amount I found dropped was £50 about 14 yrs ago.) also at work helping to arrange a meeting to support a young person in Care. I do enjoy my work ( Youth Work) as it is satisfying to make a difference and help young people move forward in their lives. As I had a difficult upbringing I can identify with issues such as domestic violence, and really try to support young people get into college / training and improve their lives in general. I know this is a long post, thank you for reading. I hope to get some sleep finally. I do wonder about another 4 yrs on this medication too! I hope that you can catch up on sleep too. Love Judith xx
Posts.Title: what drug better than anastrozole?

Posts.Content: Hi Helen, You are right the staff I saw prior to my WLE & Radiography did not warm me of the side effects or possibility of Lymphoedema and Celullitis. I was urged to do the exercises following the op, which I did regularly. I cannot lie on the side of breast op either. I've started penicillin V Potassium 500mg x2 daily for 3 months so hope the swelling and pain goes/ subsides. My mum slipped and fell in her flat, lives alone since dad died 3 yrs ago. Waiting for Social Services to provide a panic button. She's much better thanks, and eating well in hospital. I felt tired all day yesterday but better today. If you do possibly have Cellulitis ( or Lymphoedema) please let your. GP or BC Nurse know about your concerns and get it checked out. Cellulitis can just hang on in there and can get worse without treatment. I normally have lots of energy, so am making myself go out and take walks etc. Sun today which is good! Love Judithxx

Posts.Content: Hi Beavergirl, I was diagnosed in Nov 2013, had op, Rads Jan- Feb 2014, started Anastrozole Dec 6th 2013, for 5 yrs initially though the Onc said 10 yrs in Oct 2014 (?).  I was 56 yrs and post menopausal & had back pain, aches pains , depression, insomnia. So on recommendation I changed brands and was eventually asked by the Onc if I wanted to try Letrozole ( Femara) or Tamoxifen instead.  But knowing that in some cases Tamoxifen can result in other SEs.  I said no. Last Dec 2014, the local Pharmacist ran out of Anastrozole & he provided me with one month's supply of the original drug:  Arimidex made by Astra Zeneca and I noticed an immediate difference in a decrease for me of SE. So I persuaded my GP to write me a prescription for Arimidex instead.  I still have insomnia and feel tired 80% of the time, but I don't get the aching joints any more. Judithxx

Posts.Title: Really bloody angry !!!

Posts.Content: Hi Pepys, I wish I knew what the answer could be in this case. My own situation was a WLE, 4 lymph nodes removed ( Nov 2013)  followed by Rads. Rads ended Feb 2014, I subsequently had a few bouts of Cellulitis & great pain ( different antibiotics given), then developed Lymphoedema  both were contained within the breast operated on. I had a consultation (referral via my diamond GP), with Lymphoedema Consultant Professor Mortimer at The Royal Marsden in Surrey Oct 14, who officially diagnosed Cellulitis, & Lymphoedema and accordingly prescribed Prophalatic  penicillin 500mg for a year initially. I am now a member of The Lymphoedema Support Network LSN www. lymphoedema.org There are recommendations on www about the  specific antibiotics to be requested from GP. Radiotherapy may produce further side effects. It may be useful to enquire about different antibiotics if you are in pain as untreated Cellulitis may lead to an emergency  and hospital treatment. I would be inclined to see what can be done for the infection, before having Radiotherapy on an inflamed site. I hope you get some further answers from the hospital specialists. Thinking of you. Judith xx

Posts.Content: Very interesting. I agree with what you say & what George says. It is up to the individual to find a healthy balance that suits them I feel. I don't eat meat at all, as don't like it. Also nut spreads, rye crackers I do get cravings for chocolate ( usually when tired due to Anastrozone). I do eat strong cheddar cheese and have full fat organic milk in coffee and tea.  I take Ad Cal D3 1500mg 2x day in addition to Anastrozole. I don't drink enough water: generally don't feel thirsty.  I also take Vitabiotics Wellwoman 50+ Vits/ mins and feel absolutely no difference on it ( so far). I am on my second month's of taking. I'm open to taking further supplements eg Glucosamine Chondroitin etc but confused as to what exactly would be beneficial, apart from 8 hours sleep at night ..which I can only dream of. ... Posts.Content: Hi Maria, A BIG welcome back to the forum :-) x I recall your posts too, because I have the opposite to you in a way ie only one family member!  Families as the saying goes: you cannot choose them like your friends.  I agree with the other ladies' comments on here. Look at the picture objectively from the outside if you can. How would you advise a close friend who asked you for advice about this scenario?  Think of the people who ARE there for you & don't give the " power" to those who are apparently not, would be a good way of thinking about it I suggest. But yes, it is easier said than done.  My mother is 91 in hospital following a fall in Dec and I'm currently going tbrought the process of trying to find suitable residential accommodation for her in N Wales. I'm doing this completely on my own. Mum does not know that I had early stage BC in Nov 2013, as she cannot take any kind of shock due to her nervous and depressive nature. My ex split up with me the year I was diagnosed. I have no children. So you do have people on "your side " which is a blessing. The family that care about you will stick with you through thick and thin! Wish you well. Love Judith xx

Posts.Content: Hi Carol (Bosley Dog),  I had the results  to a CT Scan done July 31st, last Wed. The Senior Consultant went through it in detail and was lovely. The breast pain I have in operated breast IS as a cause of Radiotherapy. It is Tietze's Syndrome, one of the triggers is inflammation caused by Radiotherapy : Radiation.  So a relief not anything serious. He also let me know that I have Arthritis in the left hip ! This explains why I have pain all the time ( more or less) in that region.  So, now I want to know what is it exactly? The type and how to treat it? Also has the Radiotherapy made it worse etc etc etc! I have always been fit and done loads of walking: maybe I have worn it out? But I'm 58 not 85?   I  am taking Arimidex Astra Zeneca: started  on Anastrozole Dec 2013, various brands & had various side effects. Arimidex is the best for me now. Am I on it for 5 or 10 yrs? don't think I can stand 10 yrs of it!!! I can't take cod liver oil as repeats on me with gastro/ nausea etc. :-/. I am thinking of seeing a Nutritionist as would like more reliable information regarding vitamins/ minerals/ supplements and what to take? When I asked the Consultant if I should be taking VitK : 2 Mk4 or Mk7 along with the Vit D to aid absorption in the bones; he seemed suprised and repeated  AdCal VitD3, which I know about already & take on prescription.    So I did not get any information on vitamins there!  :-/  I am probably going across to the Miserable Cows' Club now as I feel more moaning coming along !! Love Judith Xx

Posts.Content: Hi Lynne, Yes there are compression garments available, the area needs to be diagnosed and measured to help with this treatment. A Lymphoedema clinic / Nurse is the first port of call. My GP detected the Lymphoedema (& Cellulitis) in my breast which was operated on, last November. Lymphoedema is a side effect which may happen in the op area, or arm/ hand at any stage, as the Lymph Node Removal ( & Rads) may cause this condition, there is a build up of Lymph fluid as the drainage system has been damaged. It may be that in due course I will wear a compression garment on my chest,or have taping, I will know after appointment with Lymphoedema Consultant Peter Mortimer next month. I have Cellulitis at present, just 3 days to go now of Amoxicillin:though in some cases people have to take low dose of anti biotics for life to reduce reoccurrence of Cellulitis. The Lymphoedema Support Network has lots of useful information & and an online forum. www.lymphoedema.org.uk Wish you well Judith xx

Posts.Content: Hi SusieB, I developed Cellulitis after. WLE & 4 LNs removed in Nov 2013. In 2014, I had Rads Jan- Feb and then got Lymphoedema in the op Breast.  I saw a Lymphoedema Consultant Professor Peter Mortimer who put me on antibiotics initially for a year. Luckily the area has recovered ( touch wood). I don't wear under wired bras any more.  I am aware that I have to be aware of the quadrant of the body which had the lumpectomy & lymph node removal for the future. As Lymphoedema can set in again at any point so I'm aware not to cause damage cuts, burns, skin breakages to the quadrant of the body that Lymph fluid flows around.  Lots of useful information about managing Lymphoedema ( & prevention) can be found at www.lympoedema.org  Judith xx

Posts.Content: Hi Sammi, I saw your post and wanted to reply, I'm awake as due to my "friend" Anastrozole. Please contact your GP tomorrow and if he /she's not kind and understanding see another in the practice. Please also contact your breast care nurse as you are still in recovery and this pain needs to be sorted out for you ASAP. Ring Macmillan Nurses too and see what they say?  I live alone too, so know that it's hard when there's no one to turn to for a hug. ( or a friendly purrrr) Though I'm thinking of a cat as had one a few years back and it did make a difference.  You are not alone on here Sammi !! When I had my treatment I saw a counsellor for three months at the Hospital, she is a Macmillan Psychological Therapies Counsellor, is there a counsellor at your hospital or Breast Care Clinic? Are you in contact with local support groups? You could ring Macmillan & find out what local community groups there are? There is also TeamUp ( Macmillan) who help with shopping, housework and such like.  Can your painkillers be changed to ones which are more effective?  I'm sending you an E HUG. Judith xx

Posts.Content: Hi Cat, Snap! I'm in a similar situation and age (57). My smear test was due in April. I had lumpectomy plus( 4 lymph nodes all clear removed) in November 13 and been on Anastrozole since Dec 6th. I had two lots of UTIs went to GP who prescribed Replens, which I take daily and the burning & UTIs went. You can get Replens free via your medical exemption certificate. Form FP92A from Dr surgery fill in 1&2. Get Drs signature & post. See online NHS for Medical Exemption Cert information. I have tried Smear Test : 3 times at local GP practice: first practice nurse(PN) said " I can give you some Oestrogen cream for that" when I pointed out that I'm ER+ she shrugged and said" you will probably need a general anaesthetic then". I left surgery feeling humiliated. She also used two speculums that did not fit ( I've not had children). Second PN was lovely, kept saying relax, but it resulted in discomfort and bleeding. Third PN was equally kind. and treated me like a human being. She said that the muscle had not been stretched for a long time ( too true. ! ) & provided me with a plastic ( small ) speculum to take away and practise stretching the area. I can see the irony in this. No Pelvic Floor Ex necessary for me!! I currently am taking anti biotic for bacterial infection in op area, so exercise in THAT area on hold :-) Be kind to yourself and please don't feel that it is a some kind of weakness on your part ( as I did). Some of my Anastrozole side effects have settled down via Replens and long walks ( joint pains). Do get a bone density scan done too! I had to chase this up with my GP surgery as GP I saw did not follow through request, subsequent GP did and I had it last month. I'm taking Ad Cal supplement with Anastrozole daily. I'm to request another scan 18 months time. Also inform/ provide copy of scan to Oncologist as Drs Surgery does not forward copies on. Try also to get support emotionally : this has been crucial for me, as in my employment I'm am a Youth Worker who provides information, advice & guidance and care. Fortunately my lovely counsellor at the Sussex Cancer Centre is extending her time & providing another 4 sessions. This brilliant site has helped me feel less alone and I so appreciate it :-) I'm sending you a virtual hug and to everyone who reads this, love to all! JMP. X.

Posts.Content: Hi Jntr, I had a WLE, 4 clear LNs removed in Nov 2013. This was followed by Rads Jan- Feb 2014.  I started on Anastrozone ( as 56y), various makes and found the side effects difficult, I then went on to take the original drug Arimdex Astra Zeneca in April 2015.  The Oncologist wanted me to switch to Tamoxifen ( or Letrozole ) last October 2014. When I said Tamoxifen increases risk of DVT and some other cancers ( and can thin hair). He did not answer. Currently I am in a lot of pain with arthritis in my left hip and pain  in the Sacro iliac joint and taking Co Codamol every four hours. It is especially painful lying down, so sleep is disturbed, and sitting, not easy as work in an office. In the morning it takes 30 mins or so for the Co Codamol to kick in & decease the pain. I sent an email to my BC Nurse asking about the % difference of recurrence if I stop taking the AI. She has not replied to my email. I have been seeing an Osteopath weekly since July and feel that my sacro iliac pain is probably caused by long term usage of Arimidex/ Anastrozole. My right side of the body is longer than the left. This has never been an issue or caused me pain until July of this year. I also have raised blood cholestrol which I read is one of the side effects of taking Arimidex. The previous GP in my practice wanted me to start Statins, I have not.  The current GP is trying to sort out my pain ( more useful) & has referred me to Orthopaedics & provided a prescription for Diazepam, when I questioned why? He said that it's a muscle relaxant and to take if the pain is severe. I don't feel inclined to take it at all. As far as I'm concerned, Co Codamol is something I would prefer to avoid. But paracetamol has not effect on the pain whatsoever.   I have only been on AIs since 2013 and the thought of being on them for either 5 or 10 years  leaves me feeling why live in pain all the time to prevent the possibility of cancer returning? Any recommendations for a comfortable mattress please? I have a Warren Evans( 2nd firmest in range think it was called Victorian)  but have had it quite a few years. It needs replacing I imagine.     I am interested to know others' views too. Thank you for reading. Judith xx

So no he did not detect bone mets luckily. Judith xx

Posts.Content: Hi Purplemarriane , Welcome to the club:-) You need to put yourself first for a change :-) There are enough people in your family to offer support it would appear.  My parents passed away in 2012,& 2016 at 90 & 92 respectively and I have no immediate family at all apart from a rescue cat who keeps me on the straight and narrow ( joke). I do have relatives miles away, distant in all senses as my mum was adopted so was her brother. On my dad‘s side there is no one.  My ex has been surprisingly supportive and visits me regularly to attend hospital appointments  with me etc. That does help a lot as I don’t always take details in due to tiredness. I also have another friend who’s been there for me. I’m 61y and was hoping to work until 67y ( thanks politicians ). Now I don’t know anymore. My work was with teenagers in a Local Authority.  For sources of support outside your family contact Macmillan and find out what‘s In your local area. Other places to offer support  are eg The Haven ( London I know of,  others you could Google), Maggie‘s Centres,(ditto),  Macmillan has monthly meet ups for people which offer support for those affected by cancer. You could see if that is offered in your region.   There is also the Penny Brohn for people adjacent to Bristol.  A lot of useful information can also be found at www.breastcancercare.org.uk   Why not set up a rota for your children to do various tasks to support their mum eg washing, housework, shopping, etc? Or if that doesn’t appear to work maybe  an increase in rent to help with expenses of travel to hospital appointments and so forth.   This will help your family to feel more involved in your care.  Macmillan in some regions offers a Buddy system where a volunteer can visit you once a week for a chat or meet you at  cafe etc. There are also Macmillan volunteers in some areas who will do light tasks eg shopping, put out rubbish for those who have no other support.  Macmillan can also advise you whether there is a Macmillan Counsellor in your area or you could find out about counselling via your GP.( might be useful for your daughter).  If sleep is an issue ( lack of) you could ask your GP if they will prescribe Melatonin? My GP would not prescribe me sleeping tablets as I’m on Chemo at present, There is also the brilliant “Awake”  discussion thread where peole can post well into the night (or day), and let off steam ..... :-)  Love Judith xx
Posts.Title: I’ve been lurking.....

Posts.Content: Hi Willow, No you are not jinxed!! It seems like this because random events of mismanagement, I would suggest have occurred. This compounded by your present health and emotional vulnerability are the factors involved, from an objective viewpoint. All the staff at Princess Royal Hayward's Heath where I had my WLE last November were so kind and professional throughout. The surgeon & anaesthetist & nurses introduced themselves to me & were reassuring & professional. It really made the experience easier. My GP has been truly inspirational throughout, from point of diagnosis up to the present time ( I never thought that I would rhapsodise about a GP ). She has totally supported me every step of the way. I currently have an organised & committed BC Nurse ( 3rd time lucky), who although extremely busy, reads and answers work emails. I saw a very kind Macmillan Psychological Therapist ( counsellor) at the Breast Care Centre at the local hospital where I had my subsequent Radiotherapy. She made very helpful suggestions for social activities, : as my ex who wanted to relive his youth,was seeing a new flame, it did not last ......:-) So I joined two support groups, so far, also been told about Odyssey ( a charity which organises breaks ). I have been on a Health Walk too, and will do more. I've tried meditation at a local Buddhist Centre with a volunteer " Buddy" organised by Macmillan for three months. The volunteer is a Buddhist, and I found meditation beneficial and relaxing. I hope this helps Willow xxxxxx When you are stronger decide what will help you disperse your feelings of hurt, anger and frustration. This site is for expressing all that we feel, and thank you for sharing. In Scotland, is there an equivalent to PALS? I wish you lots & lots of positive things!!! Look after yourself and give your husband a BIG hug: 200 miles wow. Best wishes Judith xxxxxx

Posts.Content: Hello Maggie, SaxxyD, Gn'J & everyone else this applies to. I saw Professor Peter Mortimer one of the two Lymphoedema Consultants in England, today at The Royal Marsden Hospital. He examined me and I have Lymphoedema in the breast operated on and an infection/ Cellulitis. I will be on Penicillin V Pottasium 500 mg x 2 daily for 3 months initially, then possibly on an antibiotic for propalatic long term. I have seen a local NHS funded Lymphoedema Nurse via a referral from the Onc at the hospital. I saw her three times and she could not provide MLD due to the inflammation and pain. My GP faxed a referral to the Lymphodema Consultant's Secretary and I subsequently got an appointment. The Lymphoedema Support Network which I joined £15 annual subscription: provide a medical alert card and lots of leaflets by post ( I've got very useful info from them ). When I was at The Royal Marsden Hospital the Pharmacist queried the prescription from consultant as she had never heard of a prescription for antibiotic as a propalactic long term. As I had a spare " How to treat Cellulitis" from the LSN with me, I gave it to her. She said I've learnt something today! www.lymphoedema.org.uk No one mentioned the possibility of Lymphoedema to me prior to my WLE. I think Lymphoedema is more wide spread than is known! Good luck to everyone. Love Judithxxx

Posts.Content: Hi Amanda, In terms of low immunity and recovery: I found that lots of sleep helped at the time :-) Also have short walks and try to  get daily fresh air. I take Arimidex Astra Zeneca Tabs as ER+ ( been told for 10yrs, though at time of prescription was told 5 yrs by Onc). Also take Adcal VitD at same time as Astra Zeneca. Adcal  assists the bones and prevents thinning. Diet: look at Blue Roan's  very useful blog on Nutrition :-)  I have had some side effects from Breast Cancer Treatment, please see my profile page. As strange as it sounds I bought a jar of Organic, raw, unpasteurised Sauerkraut yesterday  :which is described as vibrant & living on lid:-)! Apparently it can help your gut by assisting with the good live bacteria. I had some yesterday and it tastes fine. I am on daily penicillin to prevent recurrence of Cellulitus so interested in foods that help my gut.  Also suggest a multi Vit & min tab if you feel tired. Magnesium is supposed to help with tiredness and low mood. ( which often go hand in hand I find). Judith xx
Posts.Title: immune system

Posts.Content: You are welcome:-) If in doubt ask is what I say ! Judith xxx
Posts.Title: immune system

Posts.Content: Hi Rosalyn, My understanding is yes, otherwise how can your bones be monitored for thinning. I had a bone density scan in May 2014, which indicated that I was going towards Osteoporosis, I asked for a copy of the report for myself at the Drs as she was sent one ( but not me). I also took a copy of it and handed it to the Onc at one of my check ups , for my file there. As they weren't sent a copy either. ( Brighton & Hove area). I would ask your Breast Care Nurse for verification about all this, if she is not forthcoming or approachable, find another one; that's what I did. They are paid to provide support to people on this journey of ours. You should be able to receive information and a listening ear when you need it, and this continues after your active treatment ends too. I have put a reminder in my Phone calendar about a follow up check up bone scan, I think it's due in a year's time ( or 18 months)) need to look into that myself! You could ring and send an email enquiring about this scan & how it's arranged and by whom? You could also ask for a copy of your treatment file? If you don't receive a response, go in person to clinic/ hospital/ your GP and start the ball rolling! Wish you well. Love Judith xxx
Posts.Title: immune system

Posts.Content: Hi Amanda, I had Rads Jan- Feb 2014. You get a planning meeting to discuss the treatment and for the Radiology staff to do various measurements. You should also be getting a date for a Bone Density Scan to assess  the bone health before you have Radiotherapy . Please ask your Breast Care Nurse or Breast Care Team who organises this and when? I was not notified that I had to request it via my GP so ended up getting the test in May 2014!  The Radiologist will put tiny tatoos ( should be pin prick size), on your skin to help them direct where to line up the Rays. The tatoos which are permanent don't hurt. I had no tats previously, now I have two! One between my breasts & the other under my arm pit. Ask your BC Nurse for a Macmillan leaflet on Radiotherapy and side effects. There will be information on this www too.You may get pen marks in addition at a session, these do wash off.  My advice is drink lots of water, rest, wear a soft bra at all times, put E45 cream or similar on area 2-3 times a day,I did this for months afterwards,  dont expose that side of your body to water/sun  that's too hot, avoid cuts, scratches, knocks, carrying heavy bags etc. It varies for everyone how much time it takes for recovery, I was tired for about 3 months afterwards from the Radiotheraoy treatment. Judith xx

Posts.Content: Hi Siani, I am 57y & going through cancer forced me to look at my life and what matters to ME. I was with a partner who's emotionally needy, though intellectually very smart. I think it's a pattern as my mum (90y), has lived her life with a glass quarter full attitude to everything. My dad who died at 90 was emotionally needy with very low self esteem. Please don't accept negative comments on your abilities or perceived lack of them from anyone. Instead focus on what you enjoy and can do :-) Anger CAN be used to drive people forwards, when I was diagnosed last November: my initial reaction was I wanted to die. I had achieved much of what I set out to do. ( granted I have no family except mum). Then I wanted to attack strangers ( & blame it on cancer). So, after coming off Citalopram 20mg not long before being diagnosed, went back on it (!), and felt calmer. Now I'm on Anastrozole for 5y, have Lymphoedema, & Cellulitis, though made appointment with consultant to see how I can sort L& C out. Taking Amoxicillin at present. I have sight problems too. Walking / exercise does help ( with my mood). What support do you have from friends/ family?Can you speak to people who are there for you & won't judge? Is there a Macmillan counsellor at the clinic/ hospital where you had/ have treatment? I saw one for three months & it made such a difference. She told me about the Odyssey Holiday. Are you in touch with support groups for breast cancer survivors in your local area? Are you in contact with your Breast Care Nurse? Is there a Macmillan volunteer Buddy Scheme in your area? I saw a lovely person for three months each week. I live alone ( ex in London). Last week I went on an Odyssey Holiday : free funded by Macmillan/ donations). There were 8 women there with various health issues and we all had different experiences of cancer. My ex had stayed in my place and on my return I spent from 13:00-10:45pm in different pubs listening to his problems & how depressed he is. Relationships should not be a power struggle, but team work I think. The break with Odyssey was just what I needed at this stage, emotional support, exercise and FUN.! Use that anger to try different experiences and new things. I also have problems sleeping ( chronic snorer), I will work that one out in the future:-D . Look after Yourself , Love Judith xxx
