Posts.Title: Cancer is our own fault

Posts.Content: Hi MamaSm.  I was diagnosed with initial Breast Cancer in 2013, had a lumpectomy, 4 nodes removed ( clear), low stage 2 so had Radiotherapy only. Post op, I developed Cellulitis in op breast followed by Lymphoedema in op breast. Fortunately that resolved with a few months of antibiotics and MLD with a NHS Lymphoedema nurse ( referral by Oncologist).  Then I was  NED and to take Anastrzole for 10yrs. I actually took Arimidex ( Astra Zeneca) after  badgering the Oncologist and my GP until they relented.  In December 2017, I had backache and Diarrhoea ( which I put down to Arimidex).  The GP I saw is married to an Oncologist, and she referred me for a scan.  On 4th Jan 2018, I was told by the Oncologist that I had Secondary BC stage 4 ( Mets). To say I was surprised and devastated was an understatement !!! Mets in spine and sternum and also the major one near heart.  I asked the Oncologist what the % was for Secondary BC. Her reply was one in three. I think that if that knowledge had been available to me on completing my Radiotherapy in 2014, then I would not have felt SO shocked in Jan 2014. However, I appreciate that not everyone would share my take on things. Once there is a treatment plan in place it will become more organised. Though the shock will take time to process. I still sometimes think it’s not really true However, I have been taking oral chemotherapy tablets Capecitabine for a year Feb 2019. To start with 4x twice a day, ( SE too strong eg red and hot hands and feet and extreme exhaustion). Now on 3x am and pm and much better.  Main SE dry skin/ eyes/insomnia/ heartburn/ and lack of energy.  Also if there is  a Macmillan counsellor or Maggies Centre/ Haven,  do contact these excellent resources for complementary therapies eg massage/ reflexology/ reiki/ yoga / counselling etc.  Secondary Breast Cancer is underfunded in terms of support ie Secondary Breast Cancer Nurses. There is one, part time nurse where I live for the whole of the Health Authority !! Some areas have good support, others SNC nurses are not in place.   There are in some areas monthly social and topic meet ups for secondary breast care patients. I have been to the local one and the other ladies who attend are great. I thought it might be very depressing, but it is not. The Area SBC nurse attends  each one. The meeting is arranged via: https://www.breastcancercare.org.uk/information-support/support-you/secondary-metastatic-breast-cancer  And  https://www.breastcancercare.org.uk/information-support/support-you/secondary-metastatic-breast-cancer/living-secondary-breast-cancer-meet-groups  Keep posting and we will be here for you . Judith xxx

Posts.Title: I feel Shellshocked.

Posts.Content: Hi Lindsay,  A big welcome to the forum! It is a huge shock to receive this news and it does help to focus on what practical measures you can do at this stage. I did not have Chemotherapy, there are many many wonderful ladies on here who can answer queries in this area.  Support I feel is vital now that you are going on the treatment path. From my experience, it helps to have a partner/relative/friend with you at meetings with the Oncologist/Surgeon/Radiologist etc as I found that I could not take in and remember all that was said. If you find yourself alone at any stage request ( before hand) a nurse to be present to provide support.  Try to get all copies of appointments & reports of your treatment etc sent to you. You should receive a treatment plan  Also ensure that you can be yourself and open up to your Breast Care Nurse. This is important as they are working to support you through ( and post) your treatment programme. I was allocated a BC Nurse who was insensitive to my situation at the first meeting. The second BC nurse worked part time was run off her feet and " did not read work emails". The third was brilliant, worked full time & returned work email requests for information promptly. Try to get appointments sent in post and emailed/texted reminders to you ( sometimes post goes astray).  When I left messages for my second BC. Nurse I did not get a prompt response, so for me the answer phone message was not a good option. Maintain a good relationship with your GP, see someone else if  they're not there to fully support you.  My GP has been very supportive and noticed when I had infection post operation as I was too much in shock to notice anything much at that stage . Find out whether the clinic or hospital has a local support group for BC patients. I joined one in April of  last year, it helps. Also see if there are Reflexology or Massage sessions available to patients, my local hospital had a volunteer each Monday afternoon. Depending where you live, there are Maggie's Centres and The Haven ( google for details). I also saw a Macmillan Psychological Therapies Counsellor at the Hospital for 3 months, that helped as I had split up from my ex & was completely alone following initial Radiotherapy session.  Macmillan has a lot of useful support booklets online.  Do the exercises as recommended by the Breast Care Team, don't go bra less at all, don't wear under wired bras again, ( risky), be kind to yourself, if you feel like crying, then cry, much more healthy than bottling up emotions. Finally write a list of Questions before meetings/ appointments so you can get the information you need eg like WHO organises what exactly? I missed a basic bone density scan before starting Anastrozole as was not told I had to approach my GP to organise it. So it took place later than it should have done. Hope some of this helps. Best wishes: Judith xx. :-)
Posts.Title: Just been diagnosed

Posts.Content: Hi Karen, A very big welcome and a hug from me!! I checked your profile & in view  of your general health; I think that it would be wise to contact your GP, breast care nurse, ASAP.  ( you can still see a BC Nurse  even though you've finished treatment) and also see a Lymphoedema. Nurse in your local area. In other words, start contacting your breast care team contacts to get it investigated.  Details regarding Lymphoedema and Cellulitis, which is a bacterial infection : symptoms include pain, heat swelling and pinkness can be found on the website www.lymphoedema.org.   There are also details to be found on that www of local Lymphoedema  Consultants, I saw Professor Peter Mortimer in Oct 2014. He covers London & Sutton. Has a clinic at The Royal Marsden in Sutton and The Royal Marsden in Chelsea. Your GP could write a referral to see him ( mine did) or it may be a referral via your Oncologist/ Breast Care Nurse, just to put your mind at ease? I had a Lumpectomy, 4 LNs removed in Nov 2013, Rads which  ended Feb 2014. I had 3-4 bouts of Cellulitis 2013-14, took anti biotics.  Saw Professor Mortimer at his Lymphoedema Clinic at the RMH in Sutton he diagnosed Cellulitis & Lymphoedema in the breast operated on. I was prescribed Penicillin VK 250 mg a day for a year as a Prophalatic . I don't like taking penicillin long term, but was not at all well when I had Cellulitis. Professor Mortimer also recommended wearing a supportive sports bra ( non wired, don't suggest wearing a wired bra ever again). M&S do a 2 pack: sports bra one white/ one black. ( non wired) around the £30. To take regular exercise, he suggested swimming and to avoid extremes of temperature to that quadrant of the body. Also to avoid carry heavy items,  playing tennis, bowling or breakages of the skin on quarter side of the body. Hope this helps. Look after yourself. Love Judith xxx

Posts.Title: ER+ breast cancer & vaginal dryness

Posts.Content: Hi Sandy, Welcome to the forum! Nice to have you with us all :-) What you are describing is normal, as that is a lot to go through in a relatively short space of time. Crying  is fine, much better bottling up all your feelings. Shock affects us in different ways. When I was diagnosed Nov 6th 2013, I was in disbelief as had my told by my GP's practice nurse that I probably had Mastitis, but after two failed lots if antibiotic I was referred for a mammogram and other tests and received the news. I felt enormous rage and only cried once on the day I came home from my operation ( WLE) with my ex, who did stand by me for that period of time. I know if I'm honest that it still hasn't sunk in that I've had and been treated for breast cancer.  Not sure if it would help you to speak to someone about how you feel? I saw a Macmillan Psychological Therapies Counsellor for. 4 months at the Hospital where I had my Radiography. It really helped to speak to her each week. The hospital also had a vounteer who provided Reflexology and Aromatherapy to patients too. There are Maggie's Centres and The Haven  in various parts of the country where people can meet up and get support.  Best wishes Judith x

Posts.Content: Hi rexsi78  Yes it is difficult experiencing cancer ( twice in my case), while single. Take it day to day I imagine.  Both my elderly parents have passed away : 2012 and 2016.  I have no children, no brothers and sisters, no close family. My mum was adopted and my dad’s brother stopped contacting him in the 1950’s. I found his details some years back &  spoke to him on the phone ( as his niece), his response was a casual “ Oh is he still alive ? “ ( Nice ... so I didn’t bother again).  I found my mum’s real half sisters many years ago, through an adoption organisation. They lived in London and the South East and my mum was happy to meet them and vice versa but ....they had nothing in common.  I live alone with a Rescue cat who provides company of sorts. I had to retire on ill health grounds  from full time work as a Youth Worker for the last 18 yrs with a North London Local Authority,  which I enjoyed.  I’m now taking chemo tablets long term and have  daily stomach injections at GP ( blood thinners 1 in 10 with cancer can get DVT or blood clots in lungs).  I had blood clots in lungs which have decreased, also had a minor blood clot in leg a year ago. Started  the injections last Nov, DN calls at weekends: I hate needles !!! I hope to go on tablets instead at the start of June,  then maybe I can socialise more eg yoga Pilates volunteer gardening etc. As yet I don’t have a network of friends where I live now.  Nights are difficult, as I don’t sleep well, the Macmillan forum is a godsend. The Awake Thread on Breast Cancer is a good one to look at. Judith xx

Posts.Content: Hi Scilly , I have an aversion to needles and looking at blood ( human) so there is no way that I would inject myself ! I would probably pass out... I would rather hold a spider or snake than inject myself! I can’t say that I’ve noticed getting any colder since being on blood thinners since last  November. I do catch BBC Garden’s World for the delightful Monty Don ( Dolly the Sheep ... why can’t Monty be cloned instead imagine 1000’s of Monty Dons everywhere on the BBC on every programme..... Make a change from Huw Edwards reading the news !). I digress, yes I know about open gardens & The National Open Gardens Scheme,  the details are free online.  “Gardens Illustrated”  is a lovely magazine too, I like looking at the pictures and imaging what could be if I had more energy. I usually browse through it at a shop or supermarket. If there’s an article I like, but am not interested in the rest of mag I take a sneaky pic with my phone instead.  My way of reducing the carbon footprint. Judith xx

Posts.Title: blue boobs

Posts.Content: Hello Fiona, I am so sorry that you feel so shit at present. I'm 58yrs and had a WLE, 4LNs removed in 2013, followed by Rads 2014. Physically it took me 18months to get over the op & treatment, in the main. The physical & psychological after effects are still there, for people who go through this disease at what  ever level I think. I'm on Arimidex for 10yrs. It could be that , shock, anger, extreme fatigue, pain, despair are all there seems at the present time. (Rationally you don't know this is your last Christmas.) Lack of sleep is AWFUL, I agree whole heartedly,  it stops peolple from having the energy to do even the small stuff!! You don't have to be anything other than yourself at present. That's all any of us can be! Think about your family & how they might support you, do you feel supported by them? What did help me was to do what I could, and let the other stuff wait ( or leave it completely). Also I spoke  to a Macmillan Psychological Therapies Counsellor at the hospital where I received treatment and went back on Citalopram 20mg. My dad died & my partner & I split up around the time I was diagnosed & I have only an elderly mother: so I felt at that stage: I did not want to continue. But that feeling passed, once I started receiving support from my Counsellor, & had a course of CBT referred to by my GP.   Now I'm two stone heavier with fat  round the stomach which I realise likes me & the feeling is not mutual :-) I had pretty bad hip & back ache since July this year, I had weekly Osteopathy since July  which helped and I'm finding walking easier again. I'm sending you a BIG e hug. Love Judith xxxx

Posts.Content: Hi Heather, Thank you for your supportive and lovely reply too:-) I think heavy lifting of shopping etc and actions such as vacuuming are not recommended following surgery. My hair is not coming out too much at moment, though I'm on Anastrozole for 5 yrs, so not sure what future will bring. I started work ( gradual phased return) last week. It was tiring ( 1.5 hrs commute each way). However, it's a start. I have ultrasound and X-ray's tomorrow on op area as have what appears to be Lymphoedema, hence no more heavy lifting. Got appointment with L Nurse on Thurs morning, as confusion over times last week. I'm still doing the recommended exercises by Macmillan until I know of ones which will assist me now. Had quite a bit of back and joint pain earlier on, so trying to be positive ( though not succeeding at present). My ex has been there for me at the serious moments, operation and early radiotherapy, but it is hard otherwise, there have been times when I' be wanted to let my mum : 90yr know. But who would benefit certainly not her. I intend to join more social groups, in two at present, again it's a start. I will look into " Maggie's" too. Thank you for letting me know about that. Match.com is on the back burner too! Best wishes JMP x

Posts.Title: EYELASHES!

Posts.Content: Hello all, I've been taking Anastrozole since Dec 6th 2013. This week has been particularly bad emotionally & I've felt very down. I went through the Menopause at 52yrs and had no great sense of gloom, or depression. My side effects on Anastrozole, include lower back pain and pain in my feet. I'm taking Ad cal to counteract the bone thinning. I also have insomnia. I have not worked out which brand makes me feel worse ( though I'm on Teva at present). I got Sandoz for the next lot. I've also taken Accord too in past. Is Femara a brand of Anastrozole? My hair is also thinning too, as a result of these tablets. The Oncologist said in Feb that if symptoms persisted, i.e. vaginal dryness & UTIs, Tamoxifen could be tried in October. I don't know if that's a good idea though. I'm 57 and another 4 yrs of this is a depressing thought:-( I'm taking 20mg of Citalopram daily, ( higher doses can cause heart problems). I don't like taking anti - depressants and had come off them completely, prior to be diagnosed with Breast Cancer last November. Today neither chocolate nor a long walk helped me feel better and that in itself worried me. I had my final session with the Macmillan counsellor at the Clinic who's been wonderful & supportive. She suggested a course of CBT so I'm going to give it a go. I also have Lymphoedema in breast which had WLE. I am going to ask my GP if she can refer me to St George's Hospital to see Professor Mortimer. Or failing that see someone at the Lymphoedema Clinic there. I know breast Lymphoedema is less common than in the arm. The advice and information I've found has been on an American Lymphoedema website. Do others have this condition and any advice please? I saw a Lymphoedema nurse locally but didn't feel any difference after seeing her twice and I don't know whether I should wear an ordinary soft bra or a compression garment( not until I've had the referral). My BC nurse is on A/L until 22nd. It is hard in the middle of the night alone. Thank you for reading. Judith.

Posts.Title: Anastrozole & Depression.

Posts.Content: Hello Heather, I am so sorry that things are difficult for you at present in terms of information and support. Yes a diagnosis of cancer does have a profound impact on life. I was very scared when I received my diagnosis last November. I went for a Mammogram, regarding another problem and the cancer was picked up at an early stage. I had no symptoms or knowledge it was there. I found the Oncology Team professional but kind. The BC Nurse who was appointed to me made flippant remarks regarding my work, & I knew that I did not feel at ease in her company; so I asked for another BC Nurse who although friendly was over worked. I felt as though I was imposing on her. I too tried to get through for information and ended up leaving voice messages. If you can get the email address of your BC Nurse, ( & anyone else) in terms of communication this could save time. I'm also Oestrogen +. I had gone through the menopause already, my problem had been REALLY difficult PMS every month, year in year out. So when the menopause happened I was dreading it ... but I was very fortunate and had no hot flushes or sweats etc... amazingly. I sought counselling via the hospital cancer centre, and have been seeing a lovely Macmillan Psychological Therapies Cancer Nurse Specialist. Also I contacted a local organisation of volunteers :Cancer Buddies organised by Macmillan who provide weekly visits to your home or out and about for an hour a week. This again is beneficial for someone to be there for you and listen to your concerns and help with information. The hospital counsellor has provided a lot of support and information too eg Macmillan Team Up who will help with domestic stuff eg cleaning, shopping, if you're not up to it. Though I got through it as was not that unwell. I have tried to keep active following my WLE / lumpectomy. I had Radiotherapy following op, which was ok. I was advised to put E45 cream on the whole op area breast: which I did. Also to do the exercises following op: did them. The Radiology Dept staff were wonderful, sensitive: I cried throughout one early session. More through lack of sleep and stress. The actual Radiotherapy is fine, they play music of your choice to relax you too. If you wish. I was on my own throughout this, with some support from my ex. Any port in a storm .... :-) I had also moved to a city where I knew no one. I felt VERY tired once the Radiotherapy had ended. The fatigue went on 2-3 months, probably compounded by delayed shock. Initially on being diagnosed, I felt in a daze, up & down, very depressed some days. Went back on 20mg Citalopram, as felt anger towards complete strangers! Now 7 months later, I'm on Anastrozole for 5 years. Had 2 UTIs had anti biotic, now take Replens daily via exemption medical certificate. GP should write a prescription, when you've at that stage. My GP has been wonderful, so supportive and kind. I may have Lymphoedema in the breast. Seeing a Lymphoedema specialist tomorrow. Advice to you don't do any heavy lifting of anything on op side in future. I have had joint pain in back and knees & feet, also some hair loss due to Anastrozole. I try to eat properly and take regular exercise to counteract the pain, it helps. Did you have a base bone density scan, before you started hormone treatment? I did not realise that I had to request one via my GP as no one told me this before I started hormone therapy Dec 6th. So eventually I requested one, & had it in May. It shows that I'm going towards Osteoporosis, I have given the Oncology Dept a copy of the results for their file on me, as GPs surgery does not post them on to the hospital. Also I need to remember to request a follow up bone density scan in 18 months time, from my GP. I have also joined a local support group for women with BC. They are really friendly, supportive and offer free Reflexology, Aromatherapy and Reiki during their support meetings. Meditation can help too, I went with the volunteer to a local Buddhist Centre for open drop ins. Also yoga can benefit people too. I hope some of this helps. I'm going to attend a workshop too by an organisation called: Yes to Life. There are a couple coming up in London, see www as there are probably events throughout the UK. Best wishes JMP xx

Posts.Title: Paranoid.

Posts.Content: Hi Lyndsey, I am sorry that it's all happening at once for you. It must feel overwhelming at present! It may help to organise what you can in terms of communication with all the people involved in your care. If your Breast Care Nurse is supportive, that is wonderful! Do you have her email address to arrange or change appointments? Does she have a work mobile? Is your GP a person you can relate to and trust? Mine has been a tower of strength when I needed it. Make sure the hospital/clinic/s have your full contact details & text you about appointments: if an option. Request copies of Care Plans/ Notes that you are eligible for from the hospital/ clinic. If. X-rays are to be done, ask who will organise them? If things seem vague from medical staff, ask for clarification and get it in writing if possible. Make sure your team follow up on everything, within their capability. I'm thinking of you ! Look after yourself Love JMP xxx

Posts.Title: Chemo Survival Kit – Version 3 – 8 April 2015 - please read and contribute...

Posts.Content: Hi Gilliemck, The recovery time varies from person to person. I second the others in that it would be wise to get things checked out with your Breast Care Nurse/GP/ Breast Care Team. I had a Lumpectomy + 4 clear LNs removed in Nov 2013, followed by Radiotherapy Jan- Feb 2014. ( No chemo).  I am taking Arimidex Astra Zeneca as Hormone +. Will be on them for 5 possibly 10 yrs.  Following surgery & Rads, I then developed Cellulitis ( Bacterial infection) in operated breast: which became red, swollen, warm to touch & painful. This was diagnosed by my GP who put me on antibiotics which I took for months. www.lymphoedema.org has lots of useful information on how to recognise and which antibiotics are recommended for Cellulitis, also how to recognise Lymphoedema.  October 2014, I was diagnosed officially with Cellulitis & Lymphoedema by a Lymphoedema Consultant Professor Mortimer at The Royal Marsden in Surrey, and prescribed  Penicillin VK 500mg x2 daily initially for a year. Fortunately for me, the Cellulitis finally went. So I stopped taking Penicillin April 2015, I am left with mild Lymphoedema in the breast. The point of this email is that the side effects can go on for many,  many months. I was told that Radiotherapy side effects can take up to 18 months to settle down. The healing and repair of the body takes time & this varies from person to person. The side effects of Chemo I can't speak for. Please get the area investigated. Also do keep up the daily exercises to prevent cording and lack of mobility in your arm. I did the exercises twice to three times a day for months and had no problems with mobility. Wish you well. Judith xxx
Posts.Title: terrible pain in breast.

Posts.Content: Hi June, I read your post and would like to comment on the reference to Lymphoedema. I'm 57 ( 56 at time of op). My understanding is that  Lymphoedema is a side effect of breast cancer treatment. I am slim, take a lot of exercise, but larger in the bust than you are. I had a WLE & 4 Lymph Nodes removed, Nov 2013, followed by Radiotherapy: ended Feb 2014. The act of surgery and Lymph Node removal plus Rads may lead some people, to develop Lymphoedema.  My advice to try to minimise the risk of developing Lymphoedema, would be to wear a supportive ( non wired) soft bra following surgery as much as possible ( this was not emphasised to me by anyone), To do the recommended exercises on a regular basis; to avoid any heavy lifting on op side, avoid rough movement/ stretching, to avoid cuts/scratches/bites/ bumps  to that quadrant of the body. To avoid strong perfumed deodorants, may cause skin reaction  (also not healthy as  usually contain aluminium and parabens) ; to monitor the op area for signs of change eg redness, swelling, heat, pain : which could be indicators of Cellulitis. Cellulitis is a bacterial infection which may lead on to Lymphoedema.  Sorry to bang on about this. But being overweight  is not a reason for developing Cellulitis and/or Lymphoedema. For more information on this topic, eg   "What is Cellulitis?" and "Reducing the risk  of Upper Limb Lymphoedema" , though I have it in the trunk ie where op was, please see:  www.lymphoedema.org    I wish you well on this path we all walk together. Lots of love :-) xx Judith xxx

Posts.Title: 1st year mammogram

Posts.Content: Hi George, Regarding the Dextra Scan for Baseline re bone density. I was told when I started my Radiotherapy last Jan that I would get a scan before commencing hormone treatment. This did not happen, when I mentioned to a clinical nurse at one of my follow up checks to find out who organises it. She replied you need to speak to your GP about organising it. I had been taking Anastrozole since Dec 13, at that stage so saw GP and had Base Bone Density Scan in May 14. Results were that I was moving towards Osteoporosis. I had been taking Adcal3 twice a day in addition to Anastrozole. That is why it's SO important I feel for newbies to establish exactly who does what and get it in ( predictive text wrote " bitchin" which is far funnier :-) ) writing. I have put down a reminder in my calendar for mid March 2015 to request/ enquire about a follow up scan from my GP. Regards. Judith xx

Posts.Title: Exemestane

Posts.Content: Hi Joanne, Yes it is normal to have the pain and numbness. I had similar op in Nov and took Co-Dydramol as provided by hospital, this helped with the pain. Sleep is so important try to get it when you are able to, even if that means it's in the daytime. I've been a poor sleeper for years: as my mind won't switch off ( side effect of work). My under arm is still numb but less so, due to nerves being cut. If you can go on short walks in the fresh air ( gradually build as you get better); this may help with sleep. Try writing down your thoughts and worries too: lots of people are here for you:-) Also see if there's a Counsellor/s available at the clinic or hospital ( or GPs surgery). I've seen a wonderful counsellor since Jan. I hope this helps. My GP prescribed sleeping tablets but I did not take them as taking enough medication already :-) You could try the usual : Nytol, Quiet Life, etc from Boots. I watched lots of daytime TV in the early days to take my mind off it. And I bought myself flowers and try to eat good food and not too much rubbish :-) ( or in smaller amounts). Lots of Love JMP. xxx.
Posts.Title: Sleepless nights

Posts.Content: Hi FoxySash, Please check with your GP Breast Care Nurse etc that you don't have an infection in the breast called Cellulitis. The symptoms of Cellulitis are red/pink colour and swelling in breast, warm to touch and painful.  Also a high temperature and flu like symptoms if untreated. Cellulitis requires a course of antibiotics and monitoring. I had Cellulitis in my Lumpectomy op breast. Later I had Lymphoedema in the same breast which has fortunately gone now.  www.lymphoedema.org has a lot of information. The blue dye took a year to disappear from the op breast. Judith xx

Posts.Title: Breast Lymphoedema.

Posts.Content: Hi Chris, In October 2013, I had a change of sensation in the nipple area ( tingling)  of my right breast. I  had lumpy breast tissue and  had had so for years.    I saw a nurse practitioner who prescribed 2x courses of antibiotics for "supposed" mastitis" This did not make any difference.  When I saw my GP she asked me when I'd last had a mammogram ( I had them regularly). GP referred me for mammogram and early stage breast cancer was picked up in top right hand side of breast.  Following this I had Lumpectomy and Radiotherapy and I'm on Arimidex  for seven more years.  A few years previously I had felt a lump which turned out to be a benign cyst.  I feel that your girlfriend could benefit from further  tests e.g. mammogram/ ultrasound to provide more information in this instance. Judith xx

Posts.Title: Breast Lymphoedema.

Posts.Content: Hello, You are not alone in feeling isolated. Cancer is an experience which forces us to each evaluate our lives in some measure. This is one of hardest parts of the " Journey". I thought that 12 years ( not consecutively), of therapy would have taken care of that, but no the obligatory reappraisal of life so far and to come; once treatment :surgical & rads had been completed, has been a feature of my life for the last 4 months. My life has not been "normal" either, but as my ex would say what is normal? And how would he know? I too live alone, late 50s, no children/grandchildren, or siblings either. My upbringing shaped to an extent me today: prolonged emotional abuse from a father ( the son of an alcoholic), and a mother who was emotionally dysfunctional ( adopted and treated like a domestic servant). My parents moved quite a bit too, so I never could settle at any particular school. Not a lot of money either. I grew up wishing my parents would divorce, at a time when it was not the norm. Being an only child can definitely have its disadvantages! I also did some travelling in my 20s &30s & worked abroad, which has been enriching. My dad died at the age of 90, in his latter years I no longer felt animosity towards him. I'm aware that I could live for a considerably long time! My mother who lives in Wales is now 90 too. She does not know I've had cancer, as I can deal with my distress, but NOT her's as well. My mother's final employer died of breast cancer. Anti depressants have helped me, the ironic thing is I'd just come off them when I was diagnosed in Nov. But better to be on them for now, than have feelings of anger and aggression towards complete strangers who don't share this "experience." I have been off work since November, and since moving away from my ex : an intellectual and seemingly rational person who wanted at 50 to " have fun & take lots of drugs & date younger women" I'm now in a city where I know no one. However, I refuse to accept that this is how it's going to be for all times & I have joined 2 local " groups" because we are social beings in the final analysis! Why do people sit in pubs? ( Q for ex ) :-) My work was/is emotionally demanding and so recently having time to dwell entirely on myself has been hard. I have sought social support from Macmillan via a volunteer and also a counsellor at the hospital. You could consider this too, if groups are too much ( at this point). When I return to work, I hope to get over my non regular sleep patterns. Lack of sleep does not aid recovery... I wish you well. JMP.
Posts.Title: Alone, getting older, defeated. ..

Posts.Content: Hi Sheryl, I was diagnosed in Nov 2013, had WLE, 4 LNs removed, then Rads Jan-Feb 2014. For me it was the shock as I did not feel any lumps or see anything. It was picked up on a Mamogram as the practice nurse at my GPs sent me for one, when antibiotics did not work for what she thought was mastitis. My reaction on being diagnosed was I wanted to die ( as achieved a lot of what I'd set out to do). Then I became VERY VERY angry, at that stage went back into 20mg of Citalopram ( anti d), which I had just come off !  It took me about 18months for body to recover from lumpectomy ( had Cellulitis bacterial infection) more antibiotics, then  Lymphoedema in op breast. This has now gone or is lying low ( touch wood)!  The SE of Arimidex : anti oestrogen include fatigue ( tired 80% ), arthritis in left hip, feel 92 instead of 58 y some days :-D  But my mum who's 91y complains more about aches and pains and much else. So that is a useful warning to me ! ( she does not know I had BC). I am back at work tomorrow after spending a week with mum. I find work tiring, as since my ex split up and I moved,  now have 1.5 HR journey each way, but I have a job which is something in today's job market. Yes,  it is normal to feel angry and depressed at times!! What helps? Exercise: walks, enough sleep ( I had insomnia for months & that leads to feeling awful). Now I'm so tired from work & commute I sleep well most nights.   Try to eat well, : occasional cake ? See below :-) keep in touch with people, especially those who are positive ! Look after yourself. Love Judith xxx

Posts.Content: Hi Future, I have been taking Arimidex brand Astra Zeneca ( original) since  April 2015. Before this I was on various brands of the generic, cheaper drug Anastrozole since Dec 6th 2013.  I found my SE better since getting a prescription for Arimidex. However, when I let my Oncologist know some months back about my side effects he wanted to switch me to Tamoxifen, I replied that I didn't want to switch for another set of SE.  I am trying to commute 1:5 hours each way to work 4 days a week and feel tired 70% of the time :-(  I take AdCal but have developed pain in my left hip now.( Some people have found the Lady Magnet,  from  Boots helped with hot flushes. ) Unfortunately,  financially I need to work, though how much I can keep this up who knows. Retiring age is what 67? I wish you well, as Helen: Misty Moley says it might be worth looking into a different brand. For me the "Accord" brand of Anastrozole was the pitts!! Judith xx

Posts.Content: Hi Jess, This is unacceptable. You said that there's a family history of BC too. I agree with others' comments: follow up the whole line of communication back to your GP and check everything!  This is what I would consider doing : Find   out if there's anything you can do e.g. email your local MP ? When you email anyone (in addition to telephoning), copy in LOTS of people always  e.g. MP, MP's admin person,PALS,  your GP practice, hospital staff, local Macmillan centre,  etc etc. Don't accept waiting and doing nothing in the meanwhile.  Visit the hospital say hello to reception staff introduce yourself,  ( so they know who you are a face, instead of a number on a waiting list) Find out info in advance, look online does it give info on the BC Dept?  Send emails regularly e.g. once a week, let them know how it's affecting your health and emotional wellbeing ......and if you don't receive replies, telephone & leave messages.  Sometimes there are cancellations, you need to  be in their thoughts as much as  possible. ( in a nice way of course, always polite but PERSISTANT).  There are many reasons why lines of communication break down including: forgetfulness, items being lost, annual leave, staff sickness, changes in procedure, mistakes, laziness, lack of checking, assumptions, people not talking to each other, and so on......  As someone said on here " the squeaky wheel gets the oil " !  Love Judith xx ( originally from Gwynedd).

Posts.Content: Hi Katee,   Sally's advice is spot on!  I had a diagnosis in Nov 2013, followed by a Lumpectomy, 4 LNs removed & Rads which ended Feb 2014.  My advice would be, is to support the area by wearing a good soft ( non wired) bra. Avoid underwired bras in future. Not to carry heavy loads on op side. Avoid extremes of temperature on op side. Plus any breakages of skin.  I had 3 bouts of Cellulitis ( bacterial infection)  2013-14, followed by Lymphoedema ( mild) in breast operated on.  So at any sign of pain, redness, heat, swelling get the area checked ASAP.  I think it's better to be safe than sorry. Judith x
Posts.Title: Lymph node removal and under arm nerve

Posts.Content: Hi Murphy, I was diagnosed last November and had the WLE same month and Lymph node removal. Radiotherapy from Jan until mid Feb. I felt really tired when Radiotherapy ended. I had a phased return to work ( which is recommended by Macmillan ), and met a doctor at work ( Occupational Health Unit). It really does depend on the individual, and what sort of work you do, and your body recovering and healing. When you see your Breast Care Nurse ask her for copies of booklets such as Cancer and the Workplace, 10 top tips for Employers ( information for managers about how they can make it easier for you to return to work on an individual basis. These publications are on the Macmillan website too. You can also apply for a medical exemption certificate. My GP was great and wrote medical certificates in retrospect when I was unable to visit her. I returned to work full time last month. I wish you well for the 20th, take it one step at a time. Love JMP xx

Posts.Content: Hi Puzzle, I had a Lumpectomy (WLE), 4 LNs removed in Nov 2013, followed by Rads in Jan-Feb 2014. Following surgery & Rads, I developed a bacterial infection: Cellulitis which resulted in the op breast being painful, very painful, hot to touch and pink/ red.   I was referred by my brilliant GP to a Lymphoedema   Consultant Professor Peter Mortimer, who I saw at The Royal Marsden in Sutton ( I live in Brighton).  I saw Professor Mortimer in Oct 2014, he recommended Penicillin VK 500mg twice daily for a year initially to deal with the Cellulitis. By April 2015, the Cellulliitis had gone & the Onc said you can stop with the penicillin. I had daily diarrohea too :-) Professor Mortimer also recommended keeping up with the post op exercises,&  stop wearing wired bras: as pressure of wires can impede Lymph flow in the area. He recommended a supportive, non wired sports bra instead. He said wear it in bed at night for support, which I did until the  Cellulitis went & the area settled down.  By summer of 2015 I could have Lymphoedema Massage with my Lymphoedema Nurse & so the whole of surgery & Rads took approx 18 months to settle down. I have a check up with my Lymphoedema nurse in March.  Things to avoid with the op quadrant area, are cuts, scratches,razor cuts, harsh chemicals,  burns, skin breakages, sunburn ( on Rads areas ), great changes in temperature. Also pulling eg carrying heavy bags, vacuuming, tennis: which puts stress on the area/ quadrant. Luckily I don't play tennis :-)  As I had the WLE & Rads on the right hand side, I was told to avoid injury/ damage to the right quadrant of the body ie the right side that the Lymph flows around as Lymph Node removal & the WLE put stress on the area which may not Chanel the Lymph flow efficiently and not deal with infection due the the WLE & LN removal. I carry a tube of Savlon antiseptic cream with me at all times. If I did get an infection in the area, I would seek the recommended antibiotics see www.lymphoedema.org for information. Untreated infection can lead to Cellulitis : high temperature & possibly a hospital stay. Cellulitis can result in Lymphoedema too if left untreated. Both these conditions can occur at any stage in the future. So it's important to take care & be vigilant. Important for MedicAl staff NOT to take blood pressure or put injections in the arm/ area either as this can put the area under stress/ introduce infection too. I have a Medical Card from the Lymphoedema. org. Some people wear am Medical alert bracelet in the affected arm. Not everyone develops Lymphoedema, I believe it's around 25% but I could be wrong here?  Wish you well. Judith xx A lot of useful information can be found at www.lymphoedema.org.uk

I was told also by Radiology Dept to avoid the Rock Crystals type salts Deoderants during Rads in case they set up a skin reaction.  Hope this helps. Judith xx

Posts.Content: Hi Julie, My treatment ended Feb 12th 2014. I had a WLE 4 Lymph Nodes removed followed by Rads. I now have Lymphoedema in the WLE breast. I've had 3 lots of Cellulitis in WLE breast too since operation last November & now am taking penicillin for a year ( low dose) to prevent a reoccurence of Cellulitis. I broke up with my ex last November and moved from London to Brighton where I received my treatment. I returned to work full time in London end of September and commute by train to London daily. An hour and half journey each way. I feel tired 80% of time. I'm on Anastrozole which affects my energy levels & causes insomnia. I am going to see if I can work from home one day a week as so tired these days! I have just recovered from an upper respiratory infection which lasted a month. The GP prescribed Co- Amoxiclav  which did not seem to do much. You are not alone in feeling knackered all the time :-) I've joined social groups where I now live & get involved in them at weekends as no energy in week! Wish you well and a Big Hug! Judith xx

Posts.Content: Hi Lindy, Is there a Macmillan Counsellor at the Hospital/Clinic you visit? It may be worth enquiring. I saw a lovely woman for 3 months who really was sympathetic and offered constructive advice. Macmillan also has a Buddy Scheme whereby a volunteer will visit you or meet up in the community for an hour once a week for 3 months. You could contact the Macmillan helpline and see what local support groups there are. I attend one which is held once a month at the clinic I attended. I'm 57yr so anger ( then Citalopram ) has got me through a lot of this stuff! Sending a virtual hug Judith xxxxxx

Posts.Content: Hi Broken Emi, A BIG welcome to the forum :-)  I remember my diagnosis moment well and being in total shock ( Nov 2013), my ex who was with with me at appointment was shocked too ( unusual for him). It helps to see the treatment process I feel in stages. Try to get support for meetings eg family, friends or your allocated Breast Care Nurse. They can take in what you might not. Also request copies of letters, your treatment plan. I used to  ( still do) email my Breast Care Nurse. If you don't understand anything ask for explanations and get it written down. From diagnosis point to back to phased return to work took a year for me. I'm now 59yrs. Recovery time varies for people. Be kind to yourself, rest as much as you need. Get others on board to help you with stuff eg shopping cooking cleaning etc etc. You can get through this! Love Judith xxx.

Posts.Content: Hi , I had Lymphoedema following Cellulitis in the WLE breast 2014-15. I took antibiotics daily for a number of months and the Cellulitis and Lymphoedema gradually went away. Now I carry a tube of Savlon in my bag at all times.  I am very aware of not damaging eg cuts, bruises, burns, cat bites (!), scratches, skin breakages on the quadrant of the body of the operated breast. I also carry a medical alert card from the Lymphoedema Support Network. www.lymphoedema.org  As blood pressure and injections etc cannot be done on the op side arm ever again.   Judith xx

Posts.Content: Hi JD, No I don't think you are over reacting at all. You've been through major surgery and have every right to feel ill treated in my view! I would suggest contacting PALS as you may have been placed in an area which compromises your safety. I had my WLE last November with GA, this was the first time I'd had it since tooth removal at the dentist many years ago. I had my anaesthetic injected was wheeled through to the op theatre, then wheeled back to the recovery small side room ( with nurses present) where I'd had my initial anaesthetic. No other patients were present. Then my ex collected me and we got a taxi back to my flat. I am not happy about the way you have been treated! Even if they're over stretched and just keeping it together, it's your health that matters. Why were you expected to get up & sit in front of a TV? I was encouraged and helped by a nurse to get off the bed and sit in a chair, then given a cup of tea and a biscuit when I felt ready. Do you have a Breast Care Nurse to contact? I found a lovely person at the third attempt ( who's busy but reads and answers work emails).I'm seeing her for a catch up next Monday. If you are worried about your wound, see your GP or BC Nurse ASAP. I think the steri strips come off after 7 days, but don't quote me on this. Also be very careful, follow recommended exercises, and beware of getting Lymphoedema or Cellulitis which can occur as a result of the treatment for breast cancer, which can cause these as side effects of the treatment. I am sending you a hug & wish you good luck for Thursday:-) Let's us all know on here how you get on ? Love Judith xxx

Posts.Content: Hi Kiwi Card, I had Lymphoedema in my op breast following a Lumpectomy, then  Rads(2013-14)  then got Cellulitis, followed by Lymphoedema in breast.  I had a GP referral and saw Lymphoedema Consultant Professor Peter Mortimer at The Royal Marsden Hospital in Sutton. He prescribed Penicillin V antibiotic  which I took for a few months to get rid of the Cellulitis infection. He also recommended wearing non wired sports bras for support. I wear M& S two pack £29:00. He told me not to do anything like tennis ( I don't anyway) and to avoid lifting too heavy loads on the op side.  I saw a Lymphoedema Practitioner via a referral from the Oncologist and once the Cellulitis had gone she did some MLD on the area. Gradually it got better over about 18months, There is a lot of useful information at www.lymphoedema.org    Judithxx.
Posts.Title: Possible to reduce lymphodema in arm?

Posts.Content: Hi Emily, Good idea to look into Portacath as it prevents your veins having long term damage. I did not have Chemo, but read lots of posts on here. Many people recommend Ports or Pic Lines, there will be someone along who can provide links to these soon.  It appears that Ports are not offered as standard ( though Karang/ Lynn will confirm they are in Australia :-) ).   So it might be worth asking about the options available to you in addition to Cannulas.  Judith xx

Posts.Content: Hi Jeu, I would just like to add that if the under arm and scar area is very sore & inflamed check that you don't have a bacterial infection called Cellulitis that can occur as a result of surgery and treatment for cancer.  If the area is painful hot, pink and swollen it could be Cellulitis and would require a course of anti biotics.  It is best to get it checked out.  Judith x

Posts.Content: Hi Wendy, I agree with your post. Years ago, I think that people automatically saw a cancer diagnosis as an automatic death sentence. This view has changed with modern medical achievements. I have no qualms in speaking about my experience ( obviously not st random) as  it helps me to   assimilate my experience of having had breast cancer. Judith xx
Posts.Title: How many do you know?

Posts.Content: Hello Flower 24.  Did you make the call to your GP yet? I am so sorry to hear about your daughter's and the family's loss. Very hard time for you. I know what you mean by feeling alone! I was diagnosed with breast cancer on 6/11/ 2013. My ex actually came to appointments with me. But now I'm on my own, with no family, just my elderly mum ( 90yrs) in Wales. I'm starting to make friends locally where I live now, but it's a slow process. I'm on Match.com too as there has to be ways and means of meeting prospective partners in your 50s and 60s?  I too have Lymph oedema ( in operated breast) and saw Professor Peter Mortimer at the Royal Marsden Hospital (Sutton), regarding it. Professor Mortimer works in the London area and Sutton & is a specialist in secondary Lymph oedema caused by breast cancer treatment. I had a referral from my GP. ( excellent ) to see him. In addition to Lymph oedema, I've had Cellulitis for months, in the op area also. This is being kept at bay by Prophalatic anti- biotic.  The Lymph oedema Support Network www.lymphodema.org has lots of useful information. You are allowed to contact your breast care nurse still, for information, advice and support that is if she is approachable?  I'm still in touch with mine. ( the third ) who's very kind and is interested in my progress post treatment. I had an appointment with my Oncologist on October 24th and will see him next in April.  I shall be receiving Lymph oedema treatment at The Royal Marsden in London, got my first appointment next Tuesday. Flower you can do it! Make that call please !! Love Judith xx

Posts.Content: Hi Pat, This is totally unprofessional behaviour and there is absolutely no excuse for it!  I would take this further, find out the email address by  telephone and find out (as useful for future reference: my advice would be), of the person's  (who examined you )secretary and send a polite, but factual email outlining your concerns and the obvious confusion that occurred as a result of this examination and request clarification,  and copy in your Breast Care Nurse, your GPs surgery, and anyone else involved in your treatment. Posts.Title: Confused and upset

Posts.Content: Hi LouLou, I am in my late 50s too, was diagnosed at 56 in Nov 2013, had. WLE, 4 LNs removed & Rads in Jan- Feb 2014. I was a low 2 and advised by the Consultant not to have Chemotherapy. My ex came with me to the op and first session of Rads & then I was on my own. I live alone too & know how difficult that can be.    I sought support from my Breast Care Nurse ( once I'd found a kind & sympathetic BC Nurse), my GP who was truly wonderful throughout from my point of diagnosis through to post treatment, and a Macmillan Psychological Therapies Counsellor. I saw the Macmiilan Counsellor for three months at the hospital and could let go of my feelings in a supportive environment. I contacted my local Macmillan community group and they arranged for a volunteer to visit me once a week for an hour for a chat eg local coffee shop or in my flat or for a walk. There was also the option of "Macmillan Team Up " in my local community with volunteers who organised shoping or light house cleaning eg vacuuming, but I was never that poorly.  I was off work from Nov 2013 to Sep 2014. As following op & Rads developed a bacterial infection : Cellulitis and was on Anti biotics for months, then got mild Lymphoedema in the op breast. The after effects of Radiation took about 18 months to settle down. As I'm Hormone + I took Anastrozole from Dec 2013 to April 2015 when I switched to Arimidex Astra Zeneca, which suits me better. These tablets have affected my memory to a small extent, definitely result in poor sleep, consequently I feel tired a lot of the time : 70%, I also now have arthritis of the hip and Tietzie's Syndrome ( Inflamation in the chest causing pain from the Radiation ).   Luckily, I have never had hot flushes, as did not have them during the menopause (52). Though had bad PMS every month instead! So there are some blessings:-).  Try to find what support is there in the community and on this wonderful website too! Love Judith xxx
Posts.Title: help needed re chemo or not

Posts.Content: Hi Helen,  I have really bad insomnia at present. I think it's due to Anastroze too. I don't know if it's the fillers or not? I asked my Oncologist recently  if I could try Arimidex (Registered drug ) instead to see if I could tolerate it more, and he tried to steer me towards Tamoxifen ( which I feel apprehensive about taking for 10 yrs), and oestrogen cream. When I repeated my request to try Arimidex, he  referred me to my GP for a prescription, and she referred me back to him. I don't feel supported now treatment had stopped ( Feb 2014). I feel very alone, and really little things do bug me  eg when I write full answers to posts here and don't even get a thank you! ( this is so petty I know) , and with the amount of sleep I'm getting at present, it's hardly surprising I'm feeling paranoid. Yes I feel angry, I'm on Citalopram and still feel angry. I think about stopping Anastrozole and am too cowardely to do so. I don't feel positive and get gloomy thoughts. I live on my own now and that certainly doesn't help one bit.  Though at work, I am very positive and do not show my true emotions. I saw a counsellor at the Breast Care Clinc for 3 months and that helped. My GP has referred me for CBT. and I have am appointment this week for an I initial meeting. I had an appointment  organised by the local health authority for Oct 29th and then they canacelled it and offered me an appointment tomorrow instead. My worry is that I'm going to get really angry with the counsellor ( male) tomorrow as I broke up with my ex last November too in addition to being diagnosed with breast cancer.  But maybe that is the ideal location to let it out.  Judith.

Posts.Content: I should add that it depends on where your op scars are too!  I had a WLE & 4 LNs removed through the WLE site. I'm not small and had post op swelling, Cellulitits and then Lymphoedema, ( in op breast), which took 18 months, antibiotics and Lymphoedema treatment to revover from. Posts.Title: bra's to wear after surgery

Posts.Content: Hi Lizane, This is SO stressful for you, I am  glad to hear that you have had full confirmation that the treatment can go ahead. But.. how do you get over the shock of being given an incorrect diagnosis?  Did the registrar make their  diagnosis based on their findings alone? Would it help to express how you feel to your BC Nurse and ask her if an apology would be in order for the distress caused to you? Or do you think the registrar made a genuine mistake & deeply regrets it? I think that the way the Oncologist conveyed the information to you and the impact it subsequently had on your health and stress levels; indicates ( from reading your email), that her ability to communicate with patients regarding  devasting news is currently inadequate. It may  help to express your feelings, to ensure that others don't have to experience a similar situation. People are only human, and mistakes do happen! But as we know, prevention is better than cure.  If it is not possible to speak/ see these individuals, you could consider getting their email addresses /contacting:  via their secretaries, and expressing how upsetting the whole experience has been, and that you are very relieved to finally have the "correct diagnosis". When I was undergoing treatment, I saw a Macmilan Psychological Therapies Counsellor at the hospital. It assisted me with the shock I was going through at the time of my diagnosis: Nov 20113. I had a delayed reaction and initially felt quite numb as though it was happening to someone else. Now, in March 2015, I'm still coming to terms with it, my Rads ended Feb. 12th 2014.  I wish you well. Hugs. Judith xx
Posts.Title: Told I was misdiagnosed and it's NOT bone secondaries, it's Avascular...

Posts.Content: Hi Shirleymac, I had a lumpectomy & 4 Lymph Nodes removed in Nov 2013. This was followed by Rads Jan-Feb 2014. Following this I developed Cellulitis in the op breast ( not the arm). The symptoms were pink/ red skin, heat, pain & swelling. I was placed on Penicillin VK 250 mg twice a day for    about 11months. Following Cellulitis I developed Lymphoedema in the op breast. Cellulitus can often lead to Lymphoedema.   I did not have shakiness, but I was in shock and went back onto Citalopram 20mg a day. This antidepressant helped with the feelings of rage I experienced on being diagnosed. I also went through the majority of treatment on my own. I was off  work for a year due to ill health, and then had a phased return. I am a member of Unison and they helped with information.  It may help if you could talk to your Breast Care Nurse or a Macmillan Counsellor at the hospital you attended? I found it helped me a lot. There may also be complementary therapies eg Reflexology or massage at the hospital too ? I had a few sessions of reflexology and found this helped to relax my agitated state at that time.  www.lymphoedema.org    has useful information on preventing Lymphoedema and treating it. Judith xx

Posts.Content: Hi Lindsay,  Leolady56  and everyone, :-)  I think if people are in doubt they should check with their own  Oncoligist, assuming they are on the ball ;-) !!  what is safe to take on the individual chemo regimes.  If the Oncologist is rushed, might be an idea to get their secretary‘s address and send the Oncologist an email to find out which vitamins and minerals are acceptable to take. I checked yesterday with my  excellent Oncologist. I took pics on my mobile to save time of what I’m taking to run by her ie what is safe for me to take. The SBC Nurse is unreliable unfortunately.  So, in my case I have VitD 3 and Calichew on prescription and take Tumeric powder on soup ( to take chemo tabs x2 a day), can also take 1 Magnesium tablet, allowed Cranberry tablets. Not allowed Vit K2 Mk7 tablets.  Judith xx
